campaign.story:
Follow us on instagram and twitter to stay up to date! Email us at info@kohlhaussen.com
Video track ID: Eden - Ben Khan 
A year ago I made the first prototype of an analog medium format panoramic camera. I 3D printed the parts, painted it mustard yellow and added it to my design portfolio. It worked much better than expected and garnered attention from the likes of DPREVIEW, PetaPixel, The Phoblographer and Designboom (press links at the end).
Together, with your help, I’d like to take this project to the next step by making it available to other photographers as a kit. This campaign will fund a small production run of cameras, mostly in kit-form but also as 10 limited edition pre-finished units. If successful, the business will be properly launched and production will be further developed. 
The K-Pan is a precision tool for photographers who appreciate versatility, reliability, utterly gigantic negatives and the craft of shooting on film. Most importantly, it is a camera that you can truly make your own. The K-Pan, designed to be as small and light as possible, is perfect for the traveling photographer. Your 4x5 lens + this kit can result in cinematic images like this:
This includes more than just the camera itself - our vision is to use this modular system as a foundation on which to build an open-source platform for expansion parts and accessories. These will be designed by and for end users, including myself. 3D printing is more accessible now than ever and offers nearly limitless possibilities for augmenting, improving and customizing this camera. Don't believe me? Check out 3D Hubs. 
Need spare parts? Download and print them. Want a grip for it? Print it. Want to attach your phone to it? Print a mount. Alternatively, order the parts from our website and have them printed for you. These are just some of the things in the works - seeing that I’ve gotten plenty of use out of this camera so far, I invite you to join me in further developing this system.
A gallery of photographs taken on the K-Pan can be viewed here.
Feldsee, Southern Germany, shot on Kodak Ektar
  Oslo, Norway, shot on Kodak Ektar
  CAMERA DETAILS
The idea is that you combine the kit with your own 4x5 lens. The camera you see in the video and pictures is a prototype developed around a Schneider Super Angulon 90mm f8 that has since seen several upgrades. These include a revised film winding system, a future-proofed design with higher tolerances and compatibility for more lens types. 
After publishing the initial project, we received many requests for the CAD files, the raw printed components and also for fully completed cameras. As much as we admire the notion of localized 3D printing, we realized that it will be necessary to manufacture the core hardware ourselves in order to ensure consistently high quality and functionality. Therefor we are presenting a flexible solution - the components work out of the box, however they can also be further finished to the end user's preference. 
How it works:
It shoots five 6x14cm frames per roll of 120 film
The kit comes in two main parts; the lens cone and the camera body
The body contains a removable pressure plate, dark slide and lid. The lid plate is outfitted with the film winding knobs, fastening screws and two universal cold shoe mounts. 
Loading the film is done by removing said lid plate, similar to removing the bottom plate on a Leica M. 
Focus is set to infinity by default; it can be drawn closer by inserting dedicated spacer brackets between the lens cone and body (10mm bracket included in the kit). Hyperfocal distance is your friend. 
Frank in Hyde Park, shot with a 10mm focus bracket on Kodak Portra 800
The hardware: 
Components are made of lightproof, highly robust grey SLS nylon (see picture below). Yes, the raw components are white in the video and other pictures. We've stopped using that material because it is too translucent. 
Totals to only ~350 grams without a lens
The body is 22cm wide and 9cm tall
Embedded steel screw threads 
Standard ¼-20 UNC tripod mount 
Lens mount (the “lens board”) is 2mm thick with a 33mm diameter hole (fits a wide variety of Copal 0 shutter lenses)
First generation production prototype of Fujinon lens cone
What’s left for you to do? 
You receive the grey nylon components with the metal threads and light seals pre-installed. The camera can be assembled with your lens and used right away, however we recommend making it your own by finishing the outer surfaces. We strongly believe in the DIY ethic and are excited to see how people put their own twist on it. If you would rather just leave it in its natural finish, that's fine too. The unfinished nylon material has a rather unique, almost stone-like texture to it. 
We understand that most people will like to figure out their own special setup for the K-Pan, choosing combinations that best fit their creative style. Seeing that we want to make this camera system expandable in the future, we're currently designing multi-purpose mounts for all sorts of attachments, both internally and externally. Side projects we're working on include frame masks for smaller formats and a mount enabling you to use your phone as a viewfinder and light meter. Please check out the FAQ section for further information.
The prototype finished with yellow automotive primer
THE REWARDS
By backing the K-Pan you will ensure further innovation and development of this project. You will become part of a growing collective of DIY photographers and your support will become a vital contribution to fuel the analog renaissance. This is a great opportunity for you to get involved and help us bring this project to the world.
Tier 1: K-Pan Tote Bag + Stickers
Become part of the team with a selection of high-quality vinyl stickers in an organic cotton tote bag imprinted with design diagrams of the camera. Manufactured using solely renewable wind and solar power. 38x42cm, neutral cotton color. 
Limited to 500 pieces.
Tier 2: K-Pan Camera Standard Kit Early Bird
Grab one of only 20 full-production kits at an early bird price of £230! The complete kit comprising of the camera body, a 10mm focus spacer and one standard lens cone of your choice. Our current selection of standard cones are compatible with: 
Schneider Super Angulon 90mm f8
Schneider Super Angulon 75mm f5.6
Schneider Angulon 90mm f6.8
Fujinon SW 90mm f8
Nikkor SW 90mm f8
Nikkor SW 75mm f4.5
Nikkor SW 65mm f4 (Stopped down to f16 for sufficiently large image circle)
Rodenstock Grandagon-N 90mm f6.8 (Stopped down to f22 for sufficiently large image circle)
Rodenstock Apo-Grandagon 55mm f4.5 (Stopped down to f8 for sufficiently large image circle)
Limited to 20 units, includes Tier 1. Check out the lens sourcing & compatibility sections down below.
- SOLD OUT -
Tier 3: K-Pan Camera Standard Kit
The complete kit comprising of the camera body, a 10mm focus spacer and one standard lens cone of your choice. Our current selection of standard cones are compatible with:
Schneider Super Angulon 90mm f8 
Schneider Super Angulon 75mm f5.6 
Schneider Angulon 90mm f6.8 
Fujinon SW 90mm f8 
Nikkor SW 90mm f8 
Nikkor SW 75mm f4.5 
Nikkor SW 65mm f4 (Stopped down to f16 for sufficiently large image circle)
Rodenstock Grandagon-N 90mm f6.8 (Stopped down to f22 for sufficiently large image circle)
Rodenstock Apo-Grandagon 55mm f4.5 (Stopped down to f8 for sufficiently large image circle)
Limited to 200 units, includes Tier 1. Check out the lens sourcing & compatibility sections down below.
Tier 4: K-Pan Camera Custom Kit Early Bird
If you already have a 4x5 lens that our standard selection doesn’t cover, grab one of only 20 full-production custom kits at an early bird price of £320! The kit comprises of the camera body, a 10mm focus spacer and one custom made lens cone tailored to a Copal 0 Shutter 4x5 lens. This is subject to the compatibility of your lens, contact us to check first before pledging and check out the Lens Compatibility section further down.
Limited to 20 pieces, includes Tier 1.
Tier 5: K-Pan Camera Custom Kit
The complete kit comprising of the camera body, a 10mm focus spacer and one custom made lens cone tailored to a Copal 0 Shutter 4x5 lens that our standard selection doesn’t cover. This is subject to the compatibility of your lens, contact us to check first before pledging and check out the Lens Compatibility section further down.
Limited to 60 pieces, includes Tier 1.
Tier 6: K-Pan Camera Kit with two lens cones
The complete kit comprising of the camera body, a 10mm focus spacer and two lens cones of your choice. This includes cones from both our standard selection (see tiers 2 &3) and custom made ones (tiers 4 & 5, subject to compatibility). 
Limited to 20 pieces, includes Tier 1.
Tier 7: K-Pan Bonus Bundle
Get the complete kit comprising of the camera body, a 10mm focus spacer and one lens cone of your choice, standard or custom, in addition to a signed print taken on the K-Pan. We're also throwing in three rolls of 120 film, 2x CineStill (800T and their new 50D on 120) and a roll of Japan Camera Hunter's new StreetPan. Again, custom tailored cones are subject to compatibility.
Limited to an edition of 30 sets, includes Tier 1.
Tier 8: Limited Edition K-Pan Camera Kit
Limited to only 8 units, this reward includes the K-Pan Camera hand-finished with industrial paints in black, mustard yellow, red and military green. Includes the camera body, a 10mm focus spacer and one matching lens cone of your choice. This covers cones from both our standard selection (see tiers 2 & 3) and custom made ones (tiers 4 & 5, subject to compatibility). In addition to a signed print taken on the K-Pan, we're also throwing in three rolls of 120 film, 2x CineStill (800T and their new 50D on 120) and a roll of Japan Camera Hunter's new StreetPan. Includes Tier 1.
Tier 9: Space White Limited Edition K-Pan Camera
Grab one of only two fully completed K-Pan cameras outfitted with Schneider Super Angulon 90mm f8 lenses and hand-finished to look like they've been to the moon and back (or beyond). Imagine how NASA or the ESA would finish a K-Pan for use on their EVA spacewalks. Features include 3D printed aluminium knobs, a metallic undercoat and details with artificial weathering. Includes everything from the Tier 7 Bonus Bundle and Tier 1. 
WHAT'S NEXT?
October: Whilst this campaign is running we will do one final round of prototyping to ensure that all of our upgrades work smoothly. Some goals we have for this include finalizing the designs for a new cone-body coupling mechanism, a dark slide that inserts from underneath and grippier knobs. We will also be preparing the designs for the tote bags and stickers.
November: Prototyping and testing will continue until the final production components work just as we want them to. This could take less time than expected, however we're leaving some leeway because we know there can be minor hickups along the way. In this time we will also take care of the tote bags and stickers.
December: Time to get things made. This includes the K-Pan kit bodies, standard lens cones and packaging. During this time we will also design the custom lens cones.
January 2018: Printing of the standard components will be completed and the custom cones will be manufactured. Whilst this is happening, in-house assembly will be going strong. Tote bags and stickers will be shipped whilst the limited edition photographs are printed.
February 2018: Limited edition K-Pans will be painted and finished. Manufacturing and assembly will wrap up and orders will be prepared for shipping. Website will be prepared for launch.
March 2018: Shipping. In an ideal world we would have the rewards shipped by mid-February, however we realize that the logistics of everything will most likely push back the shipping dates to this time frame. We will also launch the K-Pan website for downloading/ordering replacement and expansion parts.
March/April 2018: A photographic adventure! I'm tentatively scheduling a trip across several countries to really put the K-Pan through its paces. The intent is to then have prints made and possibly also a book. 
  WHO ARE YOU?!
Paul Kohlhaussen (me!) is a German photographer and designer based in London. I have a long history with photographic equipment, having bought, sold and tinkered with more cameras than I can keep track of. Being an absolute 3D printing nut as well it was only a matter of time until I found a way to combine these two obsessions. A couple months ago I graduated with a degree in economics and am now studying architecture. You can check out my work on my website and instagrams @paulhausen & @pelsnaps. To get this show on the road I have sought out the help of many friends, designers, photographers and business consultants to help me along the way.
DESIGN PROCESS
From the beginning the system was designed to be a simple, reliable and long-lasting solution to medium format photography, qualities that are often lacking in many modern cameras on the market. Overall, one could say that this camera is pretty low-tech. It doesn't have a lot of moving components and is completely analog - but that's just how we wanted it to be.
Early prototypes
The components are all modeled in CAD with respect to the dimensions of the fixed input variables - the lens and the film. The flange distance and image circle of the specific lens are modeled as a three-dimensional volume around which the parts are then constructed. Details are prototyped on FDM printers and tested, allowing for the final components to be printed perfectly out of nylon powder via selective laser sintering. The resulting precision and quality in relation to the tools used and time invested is unique to such additive manufacturing. 
This process is streamlined to minimize wasted resources and environmental impact. The parts are only physically made upon ordering and don't rely on mass production and warehouse storage. Replacement and expansion parts are stocked digitally for anyone to print locally, thereby eliminating the need for long-haul shipping. 
Lens Sourcing Guide
The K-Pan doesn't come with a lens so you will need to find your own. Large format lenses are plentiful and many photographers already own them, so finding them second hand is often the way to go. Sites such as eBay, MrCad, KEH and Second Hand Dark Room work great for sourcing 4x5 lenses, it's also worth checking the various film photography Facebook groups. These lenses don't have to cost much, however there are several things to look out for.
Make sure the shutter mechanism doesn't stick and has accurate speeds.
Ensure that the glass is clean with no fungus or haze. 
Check that the components aren't dented and fit together snugly on a lens board with a 34.6mm hole (Copal #0). 
A list of newer lenses can be found here, however older lenses work just as well (e.g. the excellent Schneider Angulon 90mm f6.8).
Lens Compatibility
The main important specifications are that the lens uses a Copal #0 size shutter and has a rear element that fits within the parameters for the lens cone. This usually means that anything with a rear element diameter of more than 65mm is out of the question because it won't fit through the cone mount opening. Lenses with larger rear elements (e.g. the Schneider SA 90mm f5.6 with a 77mm Ø rear barrel) will require a two-part lens cone or an XL body, both of which are in further research and development. Not all large format lenses will work with this camera and we reserve the right to reject custom cone requests if we find them to be incompatible. 
Press
PetaPixel, The Phoblographer, DPREVIEW, designboom, Core77, GQ Portugal, 3D Printing Industry, Australian Photography, Yanko Design, 3D Hubs, 3D Druck, DIY Photography, Konbini Cheese, Hypeness, Albedomedia, 3D Focus, DesignTAXI, Popular Mechanics
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
A certain level of risk is unavoidable with any project like this, however for the K-Pan it's quite minimal. The camera has already been made, tested, refined and will go through another round of final testing before production begins. I've established a solid support network and have sufficient experience in design and business operations to know what I'm doing (we're going on an adventure!). 

The main issue we could encounter is delays in manufacturing, however the nature of 3D printing means we can be flexible and responsive to such a situation. Minor design details may change (knobs, markings, etc.) but the camera kit will nevertheless remain a beautiful tool that stays true to our vision and commitment.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

It looks like your prototype has just a plain open window. Has this caused you any issues in bright sunlight? Will there be enough clearance to tape a small piece of rubylith over the window on the inside ?
3. Will it be possible to change lens cones mid-roll? This would require a darkslide, but I don't see one in your puctures. Thanks.

2. Would it be possible to make a custom cone for a Copal 3 shutter, perhaps not as part of the Kickstarter, but later on? Rodenstock made a focusing mount calibrated for a 90mm lens in a Copal 0 shutter, but the mount itself requires a Copal 3 hole. Contact me by email for dimensions.

campaign.story:
THE DANCE CARTEL PRESENTS: WET CLUTCH
WET CLUTCH at the drive-in (photo by Maddy Talias)
A COMING-OF-AGE STORY, inside of a ROM COM, disguised as an ACTION MOVIE…
COMING SOON TO A DRIVE-IN NEAR YOU 
WET CLUTCH is a groundbreaking drive-in dance experience premiering Friday, September 8th at Seaport Music Festival. In a simulated drive-in setting, cars and audience surround a group of dancers who remix and reinterpret iconic female characters from the last four decades of Hollywood and cult films.
Building off a style developed in our signature dance-party-show ONTHEFLOOR, we’re bringing the Cartel spirit to a brand-new setting, obliterating the wall between viewer and participant with a high-energy performance style that communicates as much to the body as to the brain. The show culminates with a live DJ set by our long-time collaborator DJ Average Jo - by the end of a Cartel show, everyone is dancing.
ONTHEFLOOR (photo by Maddy Talias)
  PLAY

WHY WET CLUTCH 
The Cartel’s radically diverse dancers explore a variety of Hollywood role models (ranging from badass to idiotic) in order to break apart traditional ideas of leading women and reach a layered, multiple expression of what a heroine can be. Pulling from both cult favorites like Pam Anderson’s “Barb Wire” to Angela Bassett in “Strange Days,” to more mainstream staples like Ripley in “Alien,” choreographic reinterpretations of movie tropes are designed to open up a dialogue about the cultural mythology Hollywood provides. Original video content inspired by these icons will complement, surround and offset choreography, recontextualizing those images for a modern audience.
UPCOMING WIDE RELEASE
After the Seaport premiere on September 8th, the Cartel will adapt WET CLUTCH to a host of venues, indoor and outdoor, inviting audience vehicles wherever possible. Whether on foot or in cars, audiences will automatically become part of the architecture of the live choreography, collectively rendering and reimagining a cinematic world through dance.
GOING PLACES - WET CLUTCH TOUR (photo by Maddy Talias)
HELP BRING WET CLUTCH TO STAGE AND SCREEN 
Given the massive scope of the project, even with terrific institutional support we’ve only secured about ¼ of our budget. We’re looking to our beloved audience to bring this great labor of love life at the high production value it deserves.
Donations will help support: * modular and adaptable projection design + screens and tech at our range of venues * artist fees for intensive workshops and high-endurance, sweaty rehearsals * the genesis of complex original video content * new technology to keep that video running * designing quality costumes that conjure the cinematic world of the show * the moving set pieces (TDC vehicles) that bring the drive-in to life * the tourability and future of this show across America
The Cartel is ready to launch WET CLUTCH and bring it to a drive-in near you. GET IN THE CAR (or let us borrow yours)
LEND US YR CAR? (photo by Maddy Talias)
ABOUT THE DANCE CARTEL
“This is live performance at its best… and you should go.” - Huffington Post
“ It’s haute-performance theory with a house party vibe.” - NY Times
THE DANCE CARTEL is after a new brand of dance experience.Taking note of a dance community that often serves a niche audience, the Cartel creates dances that are VIBRANT, IMMERSIVE and often PARTICIPATORY. Without sacrificing technical rigor or artistic ambition as a dance company, we endeavor to employ the social nature of dance, the charge of a party, and the sharpness of a music video to a fresh dance vocabulary that any Joe can get down with.
Since launching in 2012, the Cartel has performed at a radically diverse array of spaces - select highlights include: Ace Hotel NY, MoMA / PS 1, BAM, The High Line, OBERON/ART, The Brooklyn Museum, Summer on the Hudson, Le Poisson Rouge, Velocity Dance Center (Seattle, WA), Philadelphia Museum of Art, Bootleg Theater (Los Angeles, CA), Edward Sharpe’s Big Top, Espaco Xisto (Salvador da Bahia, Brazil), IAC Building, La MaMa Moves!, Red Hook Festival, Space Gallery (Portland, ME). The Cartel has been featured in music videos for Yoko Ono, Vic Mensa, Reggie Watts, and The Sway Machinery. Upcoming: Seaport Music Festival, Storm King Art Center.
Concept & choreography: Ani Taj Performed by The Dance Cartel //  Co-directed by Morgan Greene // Video Design: Stephen Arnoczy & Maddy Talias // Lighting design: Joe Cantalupo // Music Production: DJ Average Jo // Sound Design: John Albano // Dramaturgy: Tommy Smith
KICKSTARTER VIDEO by Maddy Talias
SPECIAL THANKS: Ace Hotel NY + Breslin Events Team, Seaport Music Festival, On the Moon Arts, Maddy Talias, Warwick Drive-In, Luke Ohlson, Aziza Barnes, Sam Pinkleton… many more
#BEYOUROWNGODDAMHERO
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
As far as we know, there is no precedent for a DRIVE-IN DANCE SHOW, so we are building a new format from the ground up - which is costly, though thrilling and worth the investment. Much like ONTHEFLOOR, touring and adapting this show to unlikely settings is a crucial part of bringing it to the broadest possible audience. A large part of that is educating venues that are not usually set-up for dance (i.e., drive-ins, music venues, outdoor parking lots) and bringing all of our tools to the table to make the show a success wherever it goes.
This requires more resourcefulness, portability and tenacity than performing in a blackbox theater or dance studio - and it’s also more expensive - but the payoff is huge.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

Dear Team CLUTCH,
3 days to go and 4.5K to raise - we're going to do it but we need all hands on deck!
TUNE IN to our KICKSTARTER LIVE this Wednesday at this link!
We'll share a bit of our process at Kickstarter HQ with a CHOREO workshop (tell your friends who wanna dance), followed by a DEMO from the show by TDC, and then Q&A with YOU, the community bringing this thing to life.

As promised, here's a VIDEO taste of WET CLUTCH @ Seaport Music Festival. | shot by Maddy Talias & Luke Ohlson | edited by Maddy Talias | performed by The Dance Cartel
Thank you for all your support thus far. This is just the first step of what we can do with WET CLUTCH - just imagine what it could be with real resources! Let's take this one across the country --->>>

TEAM CLUTCH:
What a blast to launch this beast in the incredibly cinematic cityscape of South Street Seaport. We had a rockin' premiere at Seaport Music Festival, but now we have to bring the show to Brooklyn, the Northeast, and beyond!
We've got just 8 DAYS to go on our campaign and just over 1/2way to our goal - so now is a GREAT time to spread the word to friends that can help us realize the future of this show. So tell your friends, alert your movie-buffs, holler at your benefactors, pass it to your feminist outlets - we thank you!

WET CLUTCH premieres TOMORROW @ Seaport Music Festival! This is the first of many showings to come, but this is our biggest, baddest and FREE-est to date (and the last public show until 2018).
And we're over halfway to our goal, thanks to YOU. Thank you all for your support - it is deeply appreciated, and we can't wait to see you on the Pier.

campaign.story:
WHAT IS GIVING ME LIFE (IN THE LAND OF THE DEADASS)?
giving me life /gɪvɪg mi laɪf/ idiom. gay, black slang for anything that brings you joy.
deadass /dɛd æs/ idiom. a slang term from New York City, which means to be completely and totally serious.
1. Combined together, "Giving Me Life In The Land of The Deadass” represents the journey to finding joy even in a seriously harsh world. Trust and believe, in the times we're living in, we all need it -- especially for those of us from marginalized communities!
2. "Giving Me Live In The Land Of The Deadass" is an Official Selection of the New York Television Festival's Independent Pilot Competition. 
WHAT IS THE SERIES ABOUT?
The show follows six Black and Latinx friends as they struggle to live and love in NYC. Each season will have six episodes, with each episode featuring one friend on a shenanigan-filled adventure in a city that gives “no fucks” about an earnest heart or a living wage. The series gives life to characters that are vastly underrepresented in mainstream media, and allows them to take centerstage, showcasing the complexity of race, gender, sexuality and class through a comedic but thought-provoking lens.
Check out articles about the series in Huffington Post and Essence Magazine. 
WHO ARE THE CHARACTERS?
An idealistic “artivist,”who believes she can change the world before the world changes her. She has a problem accepting reality and boundaries in the city with no limits. Her life gets more complicated when she loses her job and her college crush, Gil, rejoins her circle of friends.
A no-nonsense, career-driven, former valedictorian, who works at an investment-banking firm while studying for her GMATs. A beacon of style and taste -- she's only willing to date women and men who are socialites. She's got her whole life figured out -- but with her high standards, can she find someone to share it with?
His natural charisma, humor and deep spirituality make everyone – even strangers – want to be his best friend. Travis has found a successful, church-going, God-loving man. He has the perfect life...or does he?
A free-spirit who's been taking random jobs and turning couch-surfing into an art form, with the hopes of one day becoming a restaurateur. And although he won’t say “no” to a crazy night out or a one-night stand, he’s a romantic at heart and is looking for the right woman to settle down with. But will his wild ways get in the way of love?
A weed-smoking middle school guidance counselor who's a peacemaker among her friends. With her easy-going demeanor, Jess is everyone’s confidante. Although the ladies love her, she has a problem letting women in — afraid that they might mess with her Zen-like way of life.
A geek-chic, sci-fi fantasy connoisseur who's not afraid to let his Blerd flag fly. Conservative, Gil constantly finds himself struggling between doing what’s expected of him versus what’s truly in his heart.
Their stories are our stories. Not only do they deserved to be told, but we need to be the ones telling them. But we can't do it without you! 
JOIN THE PARTY!
Here's the deal...we're looking to raise funds that will go towards helping us complete the first season. With three episodes already produced, three more fabulous scripts in development and your help, we believe we can bring this project to the masses! Join us! Join the party! 
In order to move forward with the back half of the first season, we'll need to raise funds to cover:
In return we are gonna hook you up!
We see you as a partner in the series and want to make sure you're a part of this experience. In exchange for your help, we're offering on-screen credits, official merchandise, private screenings, exclusive on-set visits as well as limited-time rewards like on-camera appearances and much more! Check out all the cool rewards to the right, watch out for updates and join the GML Fam today!
WHY NOW?
Although we are living through "the television renaissance," we can only name a small handful of comedy or dramedy series that star diverse actors (whether it be Black, Latinx, and/or LGBTQ). The fact that we can name them on basically one hand means that we are still thirsty for new shows that challenge today's norms and celebrate the lives of people whose very existence challenge the status quo. We do exist, after all. :)
Help us push the boundaries of television!
WHY US?  
Born in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn and living throughout NYC her whole life, series creator Dafina Roberts always had a passion to tell New York stories that capture the diversity, craziness and realness that make this city like no other. Growing up with unconventional parents in a wild city spurred her desire to tell these untold stories with humanity & humor. Join this dynamic, talented and diverse group of artists as we tell the awkward and universal tale of characters who grew up different -- grew up being "othered" -- but discovered their truth and joy through the support of their crazy lovable friends.
DAFINA ROBERTS (Writer/Director/Executive Producer)
Dafina is now a producer/ writer/ director working in television, film, and theater, with a specialization in coming-of-age stories. She is currently a Kickstarter Creator-In-Residence. She has worked in Series Development & Production at Viacom. Previously, she worked with the Oscar-nominated urban youth performance company—IMPACT Repertory Theatre. She also co-produced the coming-of-age feature film, “Punching At The Sun” (Official Selection of the 2006 Sundance Film Festival and Tribeca Film Festival; Winner for Best Narrative at the San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival.) In addition, she has produced and directed live events at the Starbucks Music Series for the Sundance Film Festival as well as at MTV with the cast of “Fela! On Broadway".
SOPHIA CLARK (Producer)
Sophia Clark is a Harlem based Producer driven by a passion for humanizing and celebrating queer and POC stories. She graduated from Philadelphia’s University of the Arts with a BFA in Film Production and a double minor in Creative Writing and Religious Studies. Before she transitioned to New York, Sophia worked as the Creative Consultant for the feature-length documentary Give to Live, which focused on charitable giving and foreign aid in East Africa. Currently, Sophia works as a field and coordinating producer for WNET, PBS’s flagship station. Her work with public media has yielded multiple local Emmy-nominated documentaries and collaborations with PBS Digital Studios and PBS Learning Media.
JORDAN BATTISTE (Producer)
Jordan is a music producer and filmmaker residing in Harlem, NYC. He has appeared on MTV’s P. Diddy’s StarMaker, procured placements on various film and TV projects such as Step UP 3D, MTV’s 10 on Top, and MTV’s MADE. The success of Jordan’s work on MADE lead to his appearance on the popular MTV show as a MADE Coach. Jordan was also instrumental in the development and signing of pop artist Marco Foster to multi-platinum artist, Flo Rida, and his label imprint IMG/Strongarm. Jordan concurrently joined the Hip Hop/Pop band, Pants Velour, as keyboardist/vocalist and was instrumental (pun intended) in their signing to Tommy Boy Entertainment LLC., as well as, produced the music for Shaun T’s newest workout DVD project, CIZE. Currently, Jordan has created a production company called, The Panda Bandit, LLC., which provides original content for brands, is currently developing various original web series, and producing a feature length movie.
HASSAN EL-GENDI (Associate Producer)
Hassan (a.ka. HaZ) is a Creative Consultant and Social/Branding Strategist with a unique, approach to digital branding and marketing for entrepreneurs and small business owners. He credits the combination of his project management experience in pharmaceutical advertising and creative work across multiple media platforms (his work has been featured in radio, television, and film) with his "creatively strategic" approach; developing and executing innovative strategy to produce quality content which crafts a unique, compelling identity helping brands to stand out in today's market.
When he is not bringing value to individuals/organizations in need his services, HaZ can be found indulging his passion for food, photography, and hip-hop, as he builds his latest project: a hip-hop fueled, multi-media exploration of what connects us together entitled "all.brunch.everything."
BRADFORD BRIDGERS (Associate Producer)
Bradford is a publicist and aspiring visual creative from Fort Washington, MD. Bradford’s diverse digital media experience has supported key editorial and marketing initiatives for a number of brands and events, such as the Essence Festival, TIME 100, BET and more. A modern renaissance man, he is currently working to develop his writing, photography and acting skills. Bradford’s current passions and projects involve telling compelling visual stories that highlight and normalize queer people of color’s lived experiences in America. He currently resides in Brooklyn, New York.
LAMONDAY BAXTER (Associate Producer)
LaMonday is a creative hailing from Raleigh, North Carolina. Her background is in digital media, filmmaking, photography, and content development. She works as a YouTube Strategist for Complex Networks. While at Complex, she works as a liaison between video and development- helping to coordinate for both Complex’s Election live coverage night, and the first ever ComplexCon. By night, she is currently helping to develop visuals for The Molecule Project and streetwear brand, Sundae School. Although she has many skills, she prides herself on her passion for using media to impact content that explores various groups of people and cultures. LaMonday resides in Brooklyn, New York.
GIVING ME LIFE FAMILY
GML MVPs: Amy Ramirez, Steve Roberts, Aisha Roberts
GML CREW: Andrew Bulington, Andrew Flores, Andrew Salomone, Bahadir Gurel, Brandi Robinson, Brandon Grant, Carina Teoh, Chelsea Brett, Chris Bianrosa, Destiny Lilly, Dietrice Bolden, Dionna McMillian, Hanna Rioseco, Hiroshi Hara, Joe Orlandi, Jonathan Hudson, Kima Baffour, Linda Huang, Luisa Pascual, Matt Chao, Natalia Majette, Robert Sweeting, Roman Gest, Ryan Wolf, Stacey Jewell, Tasheema Felder
GML GUEST STARS: Alena Singleton, Alex Pires, Angie Tennant, Borris York, Devale Ellis, Karen Vigo, Kerry Flanagan, Kyle Bary, Lindsay Aster, LJ Moses, Martin Ewens, Mijon Zulu, Spencer Scott Barros
SPREAD THE WORD!
Even if you need to save your coins, you can still help us spread the word! Share our campaign on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter or website! Every bit makes a difference!
THANK YOU!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We’re living in uncertain political times. As we prepare for this shoot, we’re keeping in mind that every day holds new surprises and challenges, especially in New York City, that can affect our production and postproduction timeline. But we’re also confident we can rise to the occasion and overcome any challenge presented to us.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Since KS doesn't allow tiers to be edited once they are pledged to, check back here for updates as the project reaches certain goals!
Please check below in the example section for visual representation/approximation of what certain items will look like.
     Hello! My name is Polina, and I am a Brooklyn-based Illustrator and the owner of Canidae Studio, a webshop where I sell accessories, apparel, and art. 
Reptilia Solaris combines a couple of my favorite things - space and reptiles. I've worked on smaller-scale reptile themed projects before (including enamel pins), but this project was an absolute joy to work on, and I'm excited to share it with others who are interested in reptile accessories. 
For examples of my work, please use the link above. You can also check out my Etsy page for reviews of my previous products!
 There are 10 total pin designs created for this project, with 5 being available at 100% funding. After that, a design will be unlocked at every $200 milestone.
 I would like to keep a small element of surprise for the stretch goals, but I will reveal that beyond the asteroid belt lurks: Tegu, Ball Python, Iguana, Blue Tongue Skink, and Uromastyx. 
Pin Specs:  
Gold metal
Hard enamel 
Most pins are 1.5", with a few at 1.75" 
The limited edition Sun pin is 2" 
Rubber clutch 
Each comes with unique backing card
For the Shooting Star pledge, you will receive a custom artwork of your reptiles! This can either be sent to you digitally, or printed and shipped to you. 
   Embroidered Patch examples: (these would be 3" x 3" and 100% embroidered)
(locked goal) Dad cap preview:
  September-October: Kickstarter is live!
Early to Mid October: Funds are received, surveys are sent out
Late October: Everything is paid for and pins are put into manufacturing
November: Production time
Late Nov. - Early Dec.: Products are shipped out!
 The initial $1,000 is broken up between:
Pin manufacturing price
Misc production fees (stickers, backing cards)
Shipping costs
Kickstarter fees
Packaging supplies
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
I have prior experience with creating enamel pin designs and working with the manufacturers that I have selected for this project. 

However, even with tried and true manufacturers, it sometimes happens that there are factory delays or a bad batch of pins. I will resolve any problem that arises on this end quickly and keep in touch with backers so that they are in the loop should any delays occur.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Art is about taking risks. Join us as we become the first artist-museum team to launch a sculptural satellite into space.
A couple of years ago, contemporary artist Trevor Paglen approached the Nevada Museum of Art with a bold idea: launch the first satellite into space that would exist purely as an artistic gesture. The Museum knew that his radical vision -- Orbital Reflector -- could help to change the way we see our place in the world. Orbital Reflector is a satellite that will have no commercial, military, or scientific purpose. Instead, it will be a public sculpture, visible from the ground without a telescope -- a satellite that belongs to everyone.
Design concept rendering for Trevor Paglen: Orbital Reflector, co-produced and presented by the Nevada Museum of Art, 2017
Why does it matter?
Art gives us a reason -- gives us permission -- to look at something deeply. An artwork that pushes the boundaries of what we traditionally think of as "art" challenges the way we engage with the world. Orbital Reflector encourages all of us to look up at the night sky with a renewed sense of wonder, to consider our place in the universe, and to re-imagine how we live together on this planet. It prompts us to ask the big questions. Who are we? Where did we come from? Where are we going? What are we doing to the shared world in which we live? 
Trevor Paglen, LACROSSE/ONYX V near Cepheus (Synthetic Aperture Radar Reconnaissance Satellite; USA 182), 2008
How will it work?
Orbital Reflector is packed inside of a small (3U) satellite called a CubeSat that will be launched into space aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, anticipated for early 2018. Once in low Earth orbit, at approximately 350 miles (575 km) from Earth's surface, a 100-foot-long diamond-shaped balloon will deploy from the CubeSat. The balloon will reflect sunlight back to Earth, making the satellite visible to the naked eye. It will remain in space for approximately two months.
How can I find it?
We are partnering with the sky-watching app Star Walk 2 to ping you when Orbital Reflector passes your location (it will orbit the planet several times a day). You can also see the satellite's flight data from our website, orbitalreflector.com.
Why a diamond shape?
Orbital Reflector is a neo-minimalist sculpture, inspired by an alternative history of spaceflight that includes early Russian avant-gardists and forgotten NASA experiments. It is a work of aerospace engineering for aerospace engineering's sake.
The design has shifted from a sphere to a diamond throughout the course of development. Once we started working with aerospace engineers to build a flight-worthy spacecraft, physics played a pivotal role. The diamond shape Paglen created will be bigger, brighter, and better in flight than a sphere. 
About Trevor Paglen
Trevor Paglen is an American artist whose work deliberately blurs lines between science, contemporary art, journalism, geography, and other disciplines to construct unfamiliar yet meticulously researched ways to see and interpret the world. Best known for his documentation and critique of surveillance in the twenty-ﬁrst century, his current work with artificial intelligence and machine vision -- and his push into outer space -- is redefining the future of art practice.
Trevor Paglen, Five Classified Aircraft, 2007, 5 fabric patches, framed
The artist has long contemplated and engaged with the history and geography of satellites -- and the politics surrounding them. He has spent significant time photographing classified satellites and other objects in orbit. 
Trevor Paglen, Nine Reconnaissance Satellites over the Sonora Pass, 2008
  Trevor Paglen, KEYHOLE IMPROVED CRYSTAL from Glacier Point (Optical Reconnaissance Satellite; USA 224), 2011
In 2012, Paglen launched The Last Pictures, an ultra-archival disc of human history told through one-hundred images the artist curated. The disc is mounted to a communications satellite that is in geosynchronous orbit as we speak. While working on The Last Pictures with MIT scientists, Paglen imagined building his own satellite, one with no other function or purpose beyond being the art object itself.
Trevor Paglen, The Last Pictures, 2012, commissioned and presented by Creative Time
Trevor Paglen’s work is included in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art; the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art; the Smithsonian American Art Museum; the Whitney Museum of American Art; Berkeley Art Museum; the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, New York; Victoria and Albert Museum, London; and the Nevada Museum of Art. 
About the Nevada Museum of Art
The Nevada Museum of Art is not your typical art museum. While we organize exhibitions and have a permanent collection like many museums, we also work directly with living artists to push contemporary art in new directions. Remember Ugo Rondinone's Seven Magic Mountains? That was us, in partnership with our friends at Art Production Fund.
Nevada Museum of Art in Reno, Nevada.
The Nevada Museum of Art is the only art museum in Nevada accredited by the American Alliance of Museums (AAM). It is a private, non-profit institution founded in 1931. 
The Museum's Center for Art + Environment is an internationally-recognized research center dedicated to supporting the practice, study, and awareness of creative interactions between people and their environments. The Center houses unique archive materials from more than 1,000 artists working on all seven continents, including Cape Farewell, Michael Heizer, Walter de Maria, Lita Albuquerque, Burning Man, Center for Land Interpretation, and Ugo Rondinone’s Seven Magic Mountains. The Center will also house the official project archive for Orbital Reflector. A portion of that archive will be on display as an interpretive-center style exhibition when the satellite launches into space.
How can I help?
Aerospace is kind of pricey. Rocket rides aren't cheap, and neither is high-tech precision engineering. This art project requires both. The overall project budget is $1.3 million. We have already raised approximately 60% of the funds, and you can help us close the gap. 
The goal we have set on Kickstarter is the minimum amount of money we need to pay this year to ensure we have a ticket to launch. The more we raise on Kickstarter, the easier time we will have putting the finishing touches on satellite construction, shipping the spacecraft to the launch site, and lifting off into space. 
There are many steps involved in constructing the satellite, and over the course of this campaign, we will share "behind-the-scenes" photos and videos detailing the process.
The Rewards
Digital Rendering of Orbital Reflector
  Official (unlimited) Diamond Mission Sticker
  Official (unlimited) Diamond Mission Patch
  Mission Pin with Chrome Finish
  Trevor Paglen, Orbital Reflector Structural Drawing, 2017
As we progress through the campaign, we will update you with photos of the official patches - they are in production now!
  Limited Edition Collector's Patch Set of 5, Custom-designed by Trevor Paglen
 As of September 18, four of the five patches are complete. Here is a collage of the artist-designed collectors' items:
  Limited-edition (1/50) unframed Satellite Prototype Print
  Limited-edition (1/20) unframed "Nevada Auriga" Print
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Nevada is situated in North America’s largest deserts. The state has seen atomic tests, military installations, and large-scale mining operations, but also experimental communities like Burning Man and the largest land-based artworks in the world. This extreme environment is also home to the Nevada Museum of Art. Risk is in our DNA. So it comes as no surprise that artist Trevor Paglen approached the Center for Art + Environment at the Nevada Museum of Art to imagine the unimaginable. Together we embark upon an exploration of the most extreme environment of them all: outer space.

This is the first time any artist or museum has attempted to launch a sculpture into space. As we have learned from the aerospace engineers with whom we are engaged, space is inherently risky and challenging. We have taken all available precautions to mitigate those risks, but certain things are beyond our control. The launch date is a moving target and the rocket may fail on the first attempt. However, thanks to launch insurance, we can fly a second time. And, as far as the satellite construction goes, we've planned ahead. We have a backup satellite unit being built as a precaution.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Dear Kickstarter Backers,
With your visionary support the Nevada Museum of Art had the distinct honor to present one of the world’s most extraordinary contemporary artists and one of the most ambitious art projects ever conceived   – Trevor Paglen and Orbital Reflector. This complex, three-year effort took numerous twists and turns and created unprecedented global interest along the way. Thousands of news stories from around the globe including The New York Times, Newsweek, Space.com, CBS This Morning, PBS NewsHour, Wired, The Guardian, The Economist, and NBC Nightly News shared Trevor’s provocation with millions of people. The documenting the project’s final months and conclusion is posted on the . We encourage you to read it.

Hello fans and supporters,
Thank you all for your patience as we have continued to work on the challenges presented by the slow work of properly identifying the satellite amidst an unprecedented cluster (20 of 64 satellites from our mission still remain in this category, including Orbital Reflector), and the the recent prolonged government shutdown. An article published today on Dezeen presents a fairly accurate summary of the current status:
 https://www.dezeen.com/2019/03/22/orbital-reflector-trevor-paglen-design/ 
We should have more to convey by the end of the month. Onward and upward!

updates.update_userinfo: MISSION UPDATE: The unprecedented #SSOA launch and prolonged government shutdown present some mission challenges
updates.update_content: Thank you for your patience, and please accept our apologies for the delayed update. The unprecedented #SSOA launch and prolonged government shutdown present some mission challenges, which we are working to overcome. But before we get into that, please enjoy the short film that we made on the Making of Orbital Reflector. We know that you will enjoy the journey:

As of Sunday night, all is proceeding for a Monday morning, 10:32 am PST launch. We will receive an update by 6 am to confirm. Tune in to the live stream of the launch at spacex.com/webcast.
Get real-time updates via the Nevada Museum of Art social media channels, and visit orbitalreflector.com. 
Thank you for your continued support!

updates.update_userinfo: Orbital Reflector to Launch this Wednesday
updates.update_content: Ready or not, here we come!
Today’s lesson in radical acceptance: Space is unpredictable and uncontrollable. #SpaceIsHard.
Orbital Reflector is anticipated to launch November 19 from Vandenberg Air Force Base

updates.update_userinfo: Trevor Paglen responds to critics of Orbital Reflector
updates.update_content:
Over the past couple of weeks, there has been a flurry of news activity related to Orbital Reflector. While much of the press has been positive, like this PBS Newshour piece, there has also been a fair amount of criticism. 
In response, Trevor has penned a thoughtful article, Let's Get Pissed Off About Orbital Reflector, in which he details the genesis and evolution of the project, and how the artwork encourages us to think more deeply about the weaponization and privatization of space:

campaign.story:
Finally. A marathon FOR THE PEOPLE.
The New York Sorta Marathon will be the first-ever short marathon. 
ZACH BROUSSARD (FUTURE MARATHON RUNNER)
America needs this right now. 
Every day there's something terrible in the news. If you're anything like me, you're feeling down and could really use a win right now. 
That's when I set my sights on running a marathon. Based on the photos I had seen of people bragging after finishing marathons, it seemed like the quickest route to filling good again. 
But then I found out how long marathons are.
Did you know that most (if not all) marathons are 26.2 miles long?
A hard truth about marathons: 26.2 miles is way too long. Some of us are physically incapable of running that long. Some of us don't have the time to train for a race that long. Some of us are simply lazy. No matter how you slice it, marathons are for the lucky few and, I don't want to be THAT GUY, but they're also kind of body-shaming. 
I have a simple vision. I want to host a new type of marathon that's way shorter.
Instead of 26.2 miles long, The New York Sorta Marathon will only be .2 miles long. (That'll make it easier to finish!) 
The New York Sorta Marathon is TENTATIVELY scheduled for Sunday, November 12th, 2017 in New York City.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are challenges involved, for sure. But none I'm not prepared to handle.

While I've never produced an event of this magnitude, I'm coming at it with a decade of film production experience. Between that and actually being a really good guy, I'm confident things will work out.

There are also inherent risks when requesting city permits. With the funds, I intend on hiring experienced event producers who will treat it that the real race that it is. If the permitting fails, I will treat the event like a FILM SHOOT and every racer will be an ACTOR, and we will simply request a film permit with the city. There's also a slight chance the date of the event may have to switch once we start working with the city on the event.

Lastly, when it comes to hosting a live outdoor event, there is a risk of weather turning against us. This event will take place rain or shine.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: The New York Sorta Marathon is officially happening November 12th
updates.update_content:
Excited to update you with some great news: The New York Sorta Marathon is officially happening on November 12th at McCarren Park in Brooklyn. 
We received our permits. It was very complicated, but no one said running a marathon would be easy. Now we're ironing out details to make every part of this marathon, except for the distance we run, as authentic as possible. 
If you pledged $20 or more, you are already registered to run and you'll have a bib waiting for you at the VERY REAL registration booth on race day. We're looking at a 9 a.m. registration time, a 10 a.m. race time, and having you all bragging about finishing a marathon like ten minutes later. The running part is gonna be pretty easy, so don't stress out about training or anything.

Guys! We made our goal! The #NewYorkSortaMarathon is actually happening!
I can't thank you enough for the support. The race is tentatively scheduled for November 12th (providing we can get permits and such in time). There's still time to pledge and sorta run. And since I'm now actually going to order t-shirts and medals and race bibs and bumper stickers, there's still time for you to pledge and get the merch that makes you FEEL like you finished a marathon!
PLAY

updates.update_userinfo: "Brag Station" Added To Help You Post Your Post-Race Brag
updates.update_content: PLAY
Any pledge above $5 now comes with being listed on a freshly purchased domain "iFinishedAMarathon.com" where you can prove you finished a marathon, even if you didn't. Pretty cool!

I hope this marathon also addresses the other huge issue: these indulgent corporate overlong marathons also START UNREASONABLY EARLY.
This is freaking great! I hope the goal is met. Even though I’m on the opposite side of the country I will sorta run .2 miles on the day of the marathon!
I sorta love this. Live in TN so I won't be there on race day, but I look forward to kicking ass and dominating my age group.
