I was diagnosed with severe FOMO after not participating in previous Zach Broussard projects. #RaceForTheCureBoysDontCry

campaign.story:
Head to our website or Facebook to learn more!
East of the River is a short coming-of-age film about Teonna, a teenage girl, who is unexpectedly suspended from school and is faced with figuring out what to do with a day on the streets of the nation’s capital. Created in collaboration with local high schoolers, East of the River highlights the experiences of young students of color as they navigate Washington, D.C.'s overburdened public school system.
We launched under the Projects of Earth campaign, a group of projects that offer unique perspectives on humanity, culture, and life on Earth. East of the River reveals a day in the life of youth pushed out of the very institutions that we expect to help them flourish, and shows how, despite a disproportionate amount of obstacles placed on these young people’s paths, they still find ways to educate themselves and grow amidst a glaring absence of social and economic opportunities to pursue the lives they want to lead.
We couldn’t be more excited to make this film and need your support in bringing it to life. We made the decision to go all or nothing on a Kickstarter campaign because we believe East of the River features untold stories that deserve to be heard. Every contribution will help us to extend this project beyond the screen and into a tool to open up a critical dialogue and bring attention to the very real experiences of teens in the United States.
EAST OF THE RIVER AT A GLANCE
Genre: Coming of Age, Narrative 
Expected Running Time: 15 minutes 
Production Dates: October 6-10 
Filming Location: Washington, D.C. 
Tone: This film is backgrounded by harsh circumstances, but inside of the world of the young characters, there is playfulness, wonder, and all the humorous, awkward, lovable things that are a part of coming-of-age stories. 
Similar Projects:
Five Feet High and Rising (2000) dir. Peter Sollett (short) 
The Florida Project (2017) dir. Sean Baker (feature) 
Heaven Knows What (2014) dir. Josh and Benny Sadie (feature)
 WHY TELL THIS STORY, NOW
This is a story we have not heard: East of the River takes place in parts of the nation's capital that rarely receive coverage in media, yet we believe if heard, would resonate deeply with a wide audience. We are choosing to highlight the experiences of young, black female and gender non-conforming students and to cast actual DC youth attending public schools.
To expand the school-to-prison pipeline dialogue: In Monique Morris' book “Pushout,” she explains that “black girls are 16% of the student population, but nearly one-third of all girls referred to law enforcement and more than one-third of all female school-based arrests." East of the River offers a nuanced view of zero-tolerance school discipline practices that too often funnel students into the delinquency/criminal systems.
Film Should Be Inclusive: Movies belong to everyone, but not everyone’s story gets featured. Low-income neighborhoods and the people who live in them are not often portrayed with dignity and instead are often represented through violence and two-dimensional characters. We wanted to make this a narrative fiction film because we believe that gives audiences a chance to share in the experience of young people pushed out of schools rather than to see them as stark statistics. 
To make is to take action: If you’ve read this far, there is a good chance we are on the same page in saying that the current political situation is really scary. Action can come in all forms, including the way we represent people, places, and circumstances in media. By contributing to this film, we entirely count you as collaborators in this effort.
OTHER WAYS TO CONTRIBUTE
Follow our Kickstarter | Like us on Facebook | Follow us on Twitter | Follow us on Instagram 
One of the best ways to help us is by posting a link to this Kickstarter page [https://tinyurl.com/Eastoftheriverfilm] on Facebook, Twitter, or any of your favorite social networks and even by emailing someone you think might be interested in backing East of the River. Thank you!
Sample Facebook Post: Friends! Check out @EastoftheRiverfilm and be a part of bringing this untold story about teens coming of age in present day DC to the big screen! https://tinyurl.com/Eastoftheriverfilm #eastoftheriverfilm
Sample Tweet: What does a day in the life look like for teens pushed out of the public school system? @EastRiverFilmDC on Kickstarter https://tinyurl.com/Eastoftheriverfilm
MEET OUR CAST
Our method of casting has been essential to the making of East of the River. We decided to hit the streets of DC to find real youth to collaborate with. East of the River is about individuals whose opportunities have been taken away from them, and it was important to us to give opportunities back to DC teens. That means providing paid opportunities, giving in-depth acting workshops, and hands on experience on a professional set.
  PLAY

Ayiana T. Davis will be playing Teonna. Ayiana is a sophomore in the music dept. at Duke Ellington School of the Arts in DC. What we love about Ayiana is her intuitive grasp on the character, her inquisitiveness and readiness to collaborate.
Instagram @ayiana_taina
 Steloni Mason will be playing Sara. Steloni was born and raised in the DC area. She is an upcoming senior this year and recently started a business called Paws n Found. While she is an entrepreneur in school, she has always had a huge dream of becoming a big time actress and model.
Instagram @milangirl_
Malachi Mack will be playing Malik. Malachi is 14 and loves to sing and meet new people. Malachi was one of the first people we auditioned and we have adored his charisma, sense of self and fashion, and humor ever since.
Instagram @savejiirealness
MEET OUR TEAM 
Writer/ Director Hannah Peterson completed her BFA at the New School in New York where she studied documentary and experimental film theory. She worked as an apprentice to Alex Gibney on the feature documentary Going Clear, the Amazon series the New Yorker Presents, and the Netflix series Cooked prior to coming to California. Additionally, she served as a staff member for the 2015 Flaherty Film Seminar. Most recently she worked with writer and director Sean Baker on his forthcoming feature, The Florida Project which had it’s world premiere at Cannes Director’s Fortnight and was recently acquired by A24. She also worked with Baker on his award winning short film, Snowbird. In addition, she has worked in various roles such as cinematographer, AD, and producer in several short films. Currently, Hannah is completing her MFA in Film Directing at the California Institute of the Arts, School of Film/Video.
Co-Writer Stacey Eunnae is a Clinical Instructor and Supervising Attorney in the Juvenile and Special Education Law Clinic at the University of the District of Columbia David A. Clarke School of Law (UDC- DCSL). Prior to joining UDC-DCSL, Stacey worked for two years as a staff attorney for Advocates for Justice and Education, Inc. where she provided direct advocacy and support to more than 150 students and their families on critical cases involving educational placements, and she successfully represented clients in school discipline hearings before charter school boards and administrative law judges. Stacey has testified before the D.C. Council Committee on Education on legislative and policy matters and she has conducted multiple community trainings on representing families in school discipline cases. Stacey received her bachelor's degree in Women Studies at the College of William & Mary, and her Juris Doctorate degree from Georgetown University Law Center.
Executive Producer Nasreen Alkhateeb is an award-winning Producer / Director, whose content has broadcast internationally for over 11 years. By motivating audiences, and empowering new voices, Nasreen thrives as a leader on diverse storytelling projects that include broadcast, digital, and film.
Nasreen has curated and created original content for NASA, BBC, NPR, The Atlantic, UNITED NATIONS, TED, SXSW, AMC, Coachella, Discovery Networks, American Film Institute, and IFC Films. In 2016, Nasreen was awarded Cinematographer of the Year by NASA.
Creative Producer Sinah Ober was born in Germany’s Black Forest to a carpenter and a tailor. She recently received her MFA in Film Directing from California Institute of the Arts (CalArts). Last fall she participated in the 2016 Telluride Student Symposium and taught a semester long seminar class, Social Media and Storytelling, at CalArts.
Sinah has worked on over 40 short films. Her films as a director have screened at several venues, including the Student Experimental Film Festival at SUNY, the International Academic Video Festival in São Paulo, and the International Kansk Video Festival in Russia, among others. She is the producer of numerous short films, including The Sacred Disease and The Creature, and her films as a producer have recently screened at the Viennale, Portland Film Festival, Baltimore Film Festival, and elsewhere. Blanco Orejinegro will be her first feature.
Director of Photography Christopher Messina is a filmmaker and cinematographer, making experimental, narrative, and documentary films. His work has been programmed in festivals and galleries around the world. His feature film credits include For The Plasma (dir. Bingham Bryant & Kyle Molzan), If There's A Hell Below (dir. Nathan Williams), and the documentary features The New Radical, and Hot Sugar's Cold World (dir. Adam Bhala Lough). His recent short film work includes Dear Renzo (dir. Agostina Gálvez and Francisco Lezama), Dead Water (dir. Andrew Gilchrist), and The Clean Up (dir. Jesse Allen). Additionally, his work as a camera operator can be seen in Josh and Benny Safdie's Heaven Knows What and Good Time, which recently had it’s world premiere at Cannes. Chris also writes and directs films, including Beijing which won the first prize for best documentary short at the Rhode Island Film Festival.
Assistant Director Ryan Daniel Browne is an Australian-American filmmaker living in Los Angeles. He is a musician and has directed over a dozen music videos. His most recent narrative film, Napalm, was successfully funded through a crowdfunding campaign, and explores teenage friendship, violence, and pyromania. It will be released in late 2017. Ryan recently received his MFA in Film Directing from California Institute of the Arts (CalArts). 
Mentor Juan Pablo González, named one of the Filmmaker Magazine’s “25 New Faces of Independent Film” for 2015, is an emerging Mexican filmmaker whose work includes documentary, fiction and experimental films. His work and collaborations have screened at film festivals such as Cannes, Locarno, IDFA, Edinburgh, Slamdance, Morelia, Full Frame, among others. He has been a grantee of the Mexican National Fund for Culture and Arts (FONCA), the Austin Film Society, and received a Jesse H Jones Fellowship for his thesis project at the University of Texas at Austin. Juan Pablo currently teaches at the California Institute of the Arts (CalArts) in the MFA in Film Directing. 
Advisor Sean Baker is a writer/director known for the Spirit Award nominated films Take Out (2004), Prince of Broadway (2008) and Starlet (2012) (winner of the Robert Altman Spirit Award). His film Tangerine (2015) premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and was released by Magnolia Pictures in the United States. Baker’s most recent film, The Florida Project premiered at Cannes Director’s Fortnight and will be distributed by A24. He is also one of the creators of the long running comedy television show entitled Greg the Bunny (2005) and its spin-off Warren the Ape (2010).
Advisor Rochanda Hiligh-Thomas has over 20 years of direct legal experience working in the DC's legal services community.  She is currently the Executive Director for Advocates for Justice and Education where she has spent more than eleven years representing hundreds of parents/students in school discipline, special education and other educational matters. The DC Bar Foundation recently awarded Rochanda the 2017 Jerrold Scoutt Prize to honor her career-long compassionate concern for her clients while exhibiting a high degree of skill representing them. Rochanda is a native Washingtonian and graduate of a DC public high school, as well as the proud mother of four children who attend a public school in DC.
Our Youth Advisory board is group of DC youth that will meet a total of 3 times before production to assist in the research process in order to ensure that the plot and characters are an honest representation of teenagers growing up in the DC Public School system. 
Music Supervisors Brandon Barnhart and Joseph Pollari are LA based visual artists and musicians.  
REWARDS
We've partnered with our favorite brands Kidd Bell and HOYFC to produce these special rewards that reflect our story, cast and team. Have questions about any of the reward bundles? Contact us here. 
WHAT YOUR FUNDS HELP SUPPORT
Your support will make it possible for us to work at the standard expected at A-list film festivals. Your support will help us fund equipment rentals, insurance costs, location fees, compensating the cast and crew, post-production and distribution. 
East of the River has the support of the California Institute of the Arts where Hannah is studying for her Masters in Fine Arts, and they will help us get a good amount of the equipment and insurance. Now we need your help to complete our finance plan. Please give what you can, share our links, and help us reach our goal. Every little bit helps!
TAX-DEDUCTIBILITY
Contributions made to Kickstarter count towards our all-or-nothing goal. However, they are not tax-deductible. If you would like to make a tax-deductible donation, you can do so through one of our fiscal sponsors.
Please contact us here if you wish to make a tax free donation.
(Note: donations made outside of Kickstarter will not count toward our all-or-nothing goal but are very much appreciated!)
PARTNERS
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Films are unpredictable, and production is inherently a risky game, we’re also doing some pretty unconventional things like casting real high schoolers in D.C. and filming in the nation’s capital. But, we’ve worked hard to put together an all-star production team that is equipped and dedicated to bringing it into fruition, not to mention a board of advisors including faculty members, personal heroes, and scholars who are keeping us accountable.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.title: Eternal Gratitude + Updates
support.descp: We understand that not all of us have much to spend. At $1, you'll still have our eternal gratitude, plus you'll receive exclusive backer updates throughout the production!

support.title: Social Media Shout Out
support.descp: You will receive a special shout out on the East of the River Facebook page! Additionally, you will receive regular updates throughout the fundraising and movie making process.

support.title: Special Thank You in Credits
support.descp: You deserve credit (literally)! Every contributor like you becomes part of our team who made the film happen and we want the world to know. Imagine seeing your name on the big screen…

support.title: Let Boys Be Feminine Button
support.descp: Wear it proud!You will be sent this beautiful "Let Boys Be Feminine" custom button by our friends Kidd Bell. Plus you will get a special thank you in the credits. In addition, you'll receive regular updates throughout the fundraising and movie making process.

support.title: Fighting Invisible Battles Enamel Pin
support.descp: Enjoy this beautiful "Fighting Invisible Battles" pin by our friend Sally McAdam. So many individuals fight battles every single day that aren't even acknowledged, and this pin celebrates and acknowledges how hard so many people fight every day.

support.title: East of the River Soundtrack
support.descp: Enjoy a digital link to the film's soundtrack originally composed by LA based musicians and visual artists Brandon Barnhart and Joseph Pollari.

support.title: GRL PWR Cap
support.descp: You’ll receive a GRL PWR cap by our friends at Kidd Bell. East of the River features two female leads because we think it's imperative to highlight the experiences of young women who overcome enormous obstacles.

support.title: Digital Link to Film
support.descp: You will receive a digital version of the movie within a few days of the movie’s release. You will also receive regular updates throughout the fundraising and movie making process, and of course a special thank you in our credits.

support.title: Production Stills Package
support.descp: You will receive a digital link to professional production stills from East of the River, we don't mean your typical behind the scenes photos, but a photo essay depicting the story of the film by a talented photographer. You will also receive regular updates throughout the fundraising and movie making process, and of course a special thank you in our credits.

support.title: Screening in DC/LA with Cast and Crew
support.descp: Join the creators of this film and see it in Los Angeles or DC before anyone else in a private screening! Don't tell the other incentives, but this is our personal favorite.

support.title: Student Filmmaking 101 Class
support.descp: Do you have a group of students (3-25) who are interested in filmmaking? One of our producers and director, both graduate students from California Institute of the Arts, will lead a Skype class for your students on the basics of making a film, and answer questions, as well as guide them on a one-off project!

support.title: Special Credit "Made Possible By"
support.descp: This is a major amount of money to part with and you are quite literally making it possible for us to make this film. We want everyone to know this too with a very special credit in the movie.

support.title: Customized Short Documentary
support.descp: The director, Hannah, will make a short documentary for you! It could be about you, your social justice initiative, someone you care about, your cute dog, you tell us!

support.title: Produce East of the River
support.descp: Either the name of your production company, or you as an individual, will be the very first thing people will see when they watch East of the River. "An X Production" we will even make an animated title for you if you don't already have one! (Creative direction of film at the discretion of the director).

support.title: Special Screening
support.descp: Do you have a community in mind who would enjoy a screening of East of the River? Upon digital release, we will rent out a space in your home town and have a screening for up to 50 guests.

updates.update_userinfo: Grateful for you + An update from the cutting room
updates.update_content:
Hello dear backers! 
As a vegetarian, Thanksgiving is not so much about eating Turkey for me as it is spending the time to reflect on gratitude for all the opportunity that has been given to me, and the extraordinary individuals who have surrounded, supported, and believed in me along the way. That very much includes you, and I wanted to take a moment to thank you for sharing your hard earned keep, for putting yourself out there and sharing East of the River with your communities, and for offering your gestures of support along the way.

Dear Backers, 
Thank you, from the bottom of my heart and soul, for supporting this film and for giving my team the opportunity and means to go into production. I'm excited to report that East of the River has wrapped principal photography! We filmed over the course of four days in Washington DC and finished late Monday night. I'm back in LA now and preparing to dive into post-production.

Hi wonderful backers!
It has been an exciting lead up to production for East of the River in DC. We arrived in DC and hit the ground running; filling cast roles, hiring local crew, making decisions on locations, equipment, and story. Most excitingly, rehearsals have commenced and our cast has been working diligently to develop characters, learn improvisational techniques, and prepare. Our highlight of the week was taking one of our 14-year old cast members to the premiere of the Florida Project, in which he was able to ask Bria Vinaite, who like him was cast over instagram, tips on being a first time actor.

updates.update_userinfo: East of the River awarded Panavision Grant + Other Exciting Updates!
updates.update_content: Hello Again!

updates.update_userinfo: Lots of amazing press, less than 12 hours to go!
updates.update_content:
We've got 8 hours to go, and are nearly at $16,000 from 248 generous backers, and today the press came flowing in! 
We are finishing strong, and oh so proud of the community who has rallied around us to bring East of the River to life. You have supported a female filmmaker, you have supported opportunities for DC youth to learn a skill and to be compensated, you have supported independent film, and an inner-city story, you have supported a diverse production team and crew--several members of whom identify as persons of color and/or LGBTQ. YOU ARE AMAZING.

Wow! What a truly amazing 3 weeks we've had! We are tremendously grateful to all of our 230 backers who helped us surpass our funding goal of $15,000 to raise $15,374 with still 2 days to go!
To our backers, thank you for believing in us, for raising your pledges and for spreading the word. We have been so blown away by the support, interest, and amazing press coverage this campaign has garnered. We are thankful for the efforts of the entire passionate community who rallied around the project and carried us to the finish line.

Thanks to our 194 amazing backers we are 87% to our goal with ONE WEEK TO GO! These last 7 days are crucial, as this is an all-or-nothing campaign and we have worked so hard to get this far! You can help us finish strong by: 
Sharing the Campaign https://tinyurl.com/Eastoftheriverfilm 
Sharing this tweet: Support female indie filmmakers of East of the River meet their @kickstarter fundraising goal! https://tinyurl.com/Eastoftheriverfilm

updates.update_userinfo: Coming of age in the school-to-prison pipeline
updates.update_content: We hope everyone is enjoying the holiday weekend! Firstly, we want to express our most sincere gratitude to the 187 backers out there who have supported us to 85% of our goal. As independent filmmakers, it is incredibly meaningful to be working on a film that resonates with so many people who we care about, and with whom we've never met but get to connect with through the art of storytelling. It goes without saying that we could not do this without you. We still have a lot of work to do to get 100% funded, and you can continue to support us by spreading the word far and wide:

comments.content: Just curious - how is this doing? It's wonderful that you guys have been pursuing this!

Hannah Peterson is such a kind and lovely person. She is very responsible and has a lot of patience. She is not a cocky director, she has a wonderful personality. I am sure that she will succeed in future projects because of her talent and her social skills. She has a wonderful team and she is not a jealous person or a copycat. Hanna Peterson knows who she is and she seems to be focused on her own growth at her pace. That's what I like about her, and she is very reliable.
Such an important project. Happy to see Kickstarter giving you extra love.

campaign.story:
Pope.L, a Chicago-based artist who has been making public interventionist art for over twenty years, comes to Detroit artist-run gallery What Pipeline with Flint Water Project, on view September 7 through October 21, 2017.
Flint Water Project is an art installation, a performance and an intervention that calls attention to the water crisis in Flint, MI by bottling contaminated Flint tap water and selling it as a limited art edition in Detroit.
150 gallons of water will be purchased from Flint residents and transported to Detroit for bottling and packaging. Approximately 900 bottles will be produced in advance of the exhibition, with an additional 300 bottles reserved for on-site bottling performances during the opening and throughout the run of the show.
Why is this project important?
When Pope.L was asked by What Pipeline to do a commission for Detroit, he felt that whatever he did it should not re-victimize the city as had been done too often in the past. What if Detroit could be the hero and come to the rescue of another midwest city in need?
In 2014, the city of Flint, Michigan, changed its water supply in order to save money. That decision and a host of subsequent and related decisions on local, state and federal levels created a crisis. Water quality was mismanaged, citizens were poisoned, and in the fallout of criminal charges and lawsuits many Flint residents still do not have access to reliable, safe water.
Flint Water Project will call attention to the city’s continued plight while raising funds to support Flint citizens in their struggle. Proceeds from the sales of the Flint Water art edition sold at What Pipeline will benefit the United Way of Genessee County, who will use the funds entirely for mitigating issues directly related to the water crisis.
A portion of the proceeds will also be donated to Hydrate Detroit, a volunteer-lead non-profit group assisting in combating water shutoffs and advocating for affordable water laws in Detroit.
About the Artist
Pope.L is a visual artist and educator whose multidisciplinary practice uses binaries, contraries and preconceived notions embedded within contemporary culture to create art works in various formats, for example, writing, painting, performance, installation, video and sculpture. Building upon his long history of enacting arduous, provocative, absurdist performances and interventions in public spaces, Pope.L applies some of the same social, formal and performative strategies to his interests in language, system, gender, race and community. The goals for his work are several: joy, money and uncertainty— not necessarily in that order.
What related projects has he created?
Pope.L has a long history of public intervention and community interaction in his artworks.
Black Factory
Between 2004-2006, The Black Factory toured the USA stirring up discussions about class, gender, race, and democracy. Visitors to the Black Factory were asked to bring objects that represent blackness to them. These objects were added to the Black Factory through performance, pulverization and documentation. Proceeds from the Black Factory Gift Shop Twice Sold products benefitted local organizations like food pantries and shelters; when Black Factory was at the Wexner Center proceeds benefited Big Brothers Big Sisters of Central Ohio.
Blink, 2011
For the mobile and interactive artwork Blink, 2011, Pope.L invited residents of New Orleans to share photos of what they dreamt about or what they were thinking about when they woke up. The hundreds of photos he received became a slide show representing the hopes and dreams of a city slowly rising after the devastation of Hurricane Katrina in 2005. He created a film from these photographs and on the night of October 22, the film was projected on the back of an old ice cream truck as it was pulled through the streets of the city by volunteers.
Pull!, 2013
In 2013, Pope.L presented Pull! a durational city-wide community performance piece in which rotating teams of Cleveland locals assisted in pulling a truck by hand for 25 miles, through the neighborhoods of North Collinwood, Glenville, University Circle, Hough, AsiaTown and downtown; to West Park, Clark-Fulton and Ohio City. This act was a way to connect an otherwise divided city and a chance to stir up a city-wide conversation about work.
These performances show Pope.L working in a space between community organization and an artistic practice—mobilizing individuals while attempting to address societal concerns through an abstraction of imposing themes such as labor, identity politics, and basic civil and fundamental rights.
What will your contributions support?
Rendering of Flint Water at What Pipeline
Much of the work for this exhibition is already underway. Your contributions will support the purchase of materials directly related to the exhibition such as bottling and packaging materials (1200 bottles and caps, custom fitted boxes, foam insets and mailing labels) along with construction materials (shelving, brackets, paint, wall paper) and labor costs.
Additional Support
Flint Water Project is supported by a matching grant from the John L. and James S. Knight Foundation as part of the Knight Arts Challenge. Donated dollars may be matched by this grant, doubling your contribution. Additional support comes from Mitchell-Innes & Nash in New York City and Susanne Vielmetter Projects Los Angeles.
Rewards
Two-Ply Flint Water Sticker ($15 or more), Flint Water Postcard, Signed by Pope.L ($50 or more)
Two-Ply Flint Water Sticker and Button Combo Pak ($25 or more)
Inside the Studio: Wonderful Studio Assistant David wearing a Flint Water Button
Hand Assembled Flint Water Prototype Water Bottle, Signed by Pope.L ($100 or more)
Very Limited Editioned Print, Signed by Pope.L ($225 or more)
Framed Original Sketches and Work Notes from Flint Water Project, Signed by Pope.L ($299 or more)
 Failed Wallpaper Test Print ($499 or more)
Framed original Pope.L concept sketches and work notes ($550 or more)
Black Factory Pro-Pak ($799 or more)
All You Can Eat Taco Bash with Pope.L and Team ($999 or more)
Dinner with Pope.L in Flint ($2,500)
Dinner on Pope.L's lap in Flint ($9,999)
Why Kickstarter?
Even though the physical form of the project takes place in a gallery, with the collaboration of Kickstarter, its conceptual and activist outreach can be far wider, stirring discussions about the availability and sustainability of clean water and the necessity for connectedness and community. Kickstarter can extend this project's reach, spread the word about the exhibition, and raise awareness about ongoing issues relating to water and struggle.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Flint Water Project is scheduled to take place in September. We need to reach our Kickstarter goal to create the Flint Water installation. We then face the additional task of bottling and selling 1200 bottles of Flint Water. All together we will spend three months in daily engagement and promotion of this project. 

Bottling will be physically intensive and repetitive work. What Pipeline will take on additional staff for the first time to ensure production can be maintained. Shipping will take place directly after the end of the exhibition, rather than throughout, to reduce the labor involved and maintain the installation on view.

With the cooperation of three galleries located in New York, Los Angeles and Detroit, and an experienced team who have worked on many art exhibitions at major museums and events throughout the world, we are confident all goals will be exceeded, and that Flint Water Project is an important artwork to support.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.title: Black Factory Pro-Pak
support.descp: Blast from the past! Black Factory deluxe Pro-Pak! Four limited edition products in one. All items specially chosen from one of Pope.L's most infamous public performances. You will receive a bottle of Black Factory Spring Water, a Black Factory tee-shirt, a Black Factory yellow rubber duckie, and a Black Factory Twice Sold can of Sainsbury Baked Beans all the way from the motherland of Great Britain. These works are the last of the edition from Pope.L's personal collection.

updates.update_content:
It's been one year since What Pipeline helped launch Pope.L's Flint Water Project to raise awareness, and money, for the struggles of the people of Flint. A year later Flint still does not have clean water and every day more communities are finding their access to clean water in jeopardy. 
Editions of Flint Water are still available and all proceeds are still donated to United Way Genessee County's Flint Water Fund, and to Hydrate Detroit, a non-profit working on water issues in Detroit.

updates.update_userinfo: Pope.L Flint Water at What Pipeline extended through October 28!
updates.update_content:
Hi there! We've got a few great updates for you:
First off, we've been busy selling Flint Water online, in the gallery and recently at the Detroit Art Book Fair where we got some great donations! It's be an awe-inspiring experience for us to raise money and awareness for Flint residents, and for water issues in Detroit as well.
Images from Pope.L's Flint Water exhibition at What Pipeline are now online here: http://whatpipeline.com/ and the show has been extended through October 28. We'll also have extended open hours; the gallery will be open October 25 - 27 from 2 to 7 PM. And we are always open by appointment!

We did it! The block party opening for Pope.L Flint Water was an amazing gathering with an auction, raffle, piñata, music and tacos plus hearty donations! A big thank you list became a part of the install to show our love for our backers and everyone who helped with Flint Water Project. We'll be updating you on the shipment of rewards soon. We are off to a great start raising money and awareness for Flint and Detroit water issues.
But this project is just beginning! We still need your help. The people of Flint and Detroit struggling with the impact of water issues need your help. We need to sell Flint Water to raise funds and combat those issues.

Today is the LAST DAY to pledge for the Flint Water Kickstarter campaign! If you have been considering pledging but not had time, this is it!
Flint Water Project is in great shape thanks to the backers of our campaign. We're looking forward to seeing you all at What Pipeline on Thursday, September 7, 6-9 PM for the launch of FLINT WATER!
Visit whatpipeline.com for more info about FLINT WATER, the opening and the exhibition.

Yet another goal has been met thanks to the support of our awesome backers! We've hit the stretch goal to fund our Flint Water Opening Block Party and are now busy finalizing the fun. Be sure to stop by What Pipeline on September 7 to experience the good time!
If you still want to be a part of Flint Water Project there are great rewards remaining including the Flint Water Sticker and Button combo for $25. Your pledges will be honored on our wall of names in the exhibition. There's only one week left to claim these cool rewards so don't delay, pledge and share today!

updates.update_userinfo: NEW REWARD! Pope.L Original Sketches for Flint Water!
updates.update_content:
We're making great headway towards our stretch goal in support of the Flint Water Project Opening Block Party. Now we've got another great reward to announce: four more Framed Original Sketches by Pope.L have just been added!
These sketches for the Flint Water bottle are 8.5 x 11 inch original works showing the notes for the Flint Water bottle design. These works are attractive and unique to this project, and can be yours for a pledge of $550. Hurry, only three remain!

updates.update_userinfo: Flint Water Project Opening Block Party "Stretch Goal"
updates.update_content:
Announcing our campaign stretch goal, the Flint Water Project Opening Block Party! Thanks to our incredible backers we've hit our funding goal with time to spare. We've added new rewards and a stretch goal of $17,500 to help create the Flint Water Project Opening Block Party.
This won't be your typical gallery opening! We're bringing the music, the drinks, the food, and our neighbors together to help us kick off the Flint Water Project. Our block party will take over the parking lot of What Pipeline with interactive fun for all ages, featuring raffles, a piñata, and more.

updates.update_userinfo: HOORAY WE DID IT!!! THANK YOU!!!
updates.update_content:
Thanks to our awesome backers POPE.L: FLINT WATER PROJECT HAS REACHED OUR FUNDING GOAL!
This achievement literally could not have happened without YOU! What an amazing feeling to get this kind of support, and what a fantastic beginning to the Flint Water Project. We can't wait to share this exhibition with the world.
Stay tuned for more announcements as our Kickstarter campaign continues over the next few weeks. And from everyone working on this project!

updates.update_userinfo: $10,000 is a major milestone and we just hit it thanks to YOU!
updates.update_content:
We can't say it enough, thank you for the support you've given to the Pope.L: Flint Water Project campaign. Because of you we just hit the $10,000 mark and the goal is in sight!
Please help us hit this goal by sharing a link to our campaign with your friends, on social media, and wherever you can:
http://kck.st/2vxwOs3
If you're considering a Very Limited Editioned Print only five remain.

campaign.story:
In honor of Voyager Spaceship's 40th Anniversary, Spaceship Creativity is blasting off again, this time the destination is Earth! 
Mission Creativity 2: Earth 
For the next 28 days, Commander Paint will be painting and drawing what is like to live on Earth. Politics, news, pop culture, etc, will all find their places in these paintings and drawings. You can collaborate with Commander Paint by interacting with him live on the internet (streaming at various times on the following sites: Kickstarter Live, Twitch, Facebook Live, and Youtube Live). Check for updates on Kickstarter and my Twitter feed: letspainttv. 
Voyager had the "Golden Record" depicting life on Earth 40 years ago. Mission Creativity 2: Earth is a "Golden Record 2.0" update. 
When we reach our goal of $3,000, Commander Paint will make one large 6 ft. painting depicting the life on Earth 2017. A print will be available as a reward. 
Please check out my past Kickstarters for more information about Commander Mr Let's Paint, a.k.a. John Kilduff. 
Here are some of the rewards available:
  Mission Creativity 2: Earth Patch $30
  Hand Painted T-shirt $35
 If you want an "Embrace Failare" of "Let's Paint TV" T-shirt...Go ahead and order a T-shirt and email me that you want a different image painted on the shirt.
Mission Creativity Spaceship $200
  Protesters watching eclipse $500
  Life on Earth August 22-23 $500
  Charlottesville $100
  Flat Earth $100
  "Off with their heads!" $300
  Painting of whatever you want! $100
I will paint what ever you want! How about a portrait of your cat? Dog? or loved one? 
Circus Liquors $250
  Zuma Beach $150
  Labor Day Watercolor $200
  Kim Kardashian-Venus of Willendorf-Irma $200

campaign.story:
Ai Weiwei at the US - Mexico Border, 2016
“What’s important to remember is that while barriers have been used to divide us, as humans we are all the same. Some are more privileged than others, but with that privilege comes a responsibility to do more.”    
World-renowned artist and activist, Ai Weiwei, and New York City's premier presenter of contemporary outdoor art, Public Art Fund, are working together to bring an important new art exhibition to the streets of NYC from October to February.  
In response to the worldwide plight of migrants and refugees, divisive immigration and border control policies, and the global rise in nationalism, the exhibition, Good Fences Make Good Neighbors, will be installed at 300 + sites spanning dozens of New York City neighborhoods in all five boroughs. 
Drawing on the artist’s personal experience being detained by the Chinese government and as well as his visits with some of the world’s most vulnerable populations at refugee camps and borders worldwide, the show will make a powerful statement about division and separation at a global, national, local, and personal level.
About the Artworks
"Fences can be used to regulate and detain people, to segregate and to train people to accept the given conditions."
Installation concept rendering, Doris C. Freedman Plaza
Adapting security fencing in a variety of unexpected ways, Ai Weiwei's artworks will appear at street level, rise from rooftops, emerge between buildings, be affixed to lampposts, frame bus shelters, and seemingly grow out of the urban infrastructure. 
Major site-specific sculptures will be installed at iconic locations including Central Park, Washington Square Park, and the Unisphere, while more discrete 2-D and 3-D interventions — including posters with images collected from the artist’s visits to refugee camps around the world — will be installed across New York's five boroughs.
This is your chance to be a part of Ai Weiwei’s revolutionary work by joining a community of artists, activists, and citizens standing up against the forces that separate us.
Installation concept rendering, Washington Square Park
About Ai Weiwei
"The issue with the migration crisis has been a longtime focus of my practice. And the fence has always been a tool in the vocabulary of political landscaping.”
Ai Weiwei at Idomeni Refugee Camp, Greece, 2016
Given his remarkable life and work, Ai Weiwei stands as a unique international figure. He is both one of the most celebrated contemporary artists and one of the world’s most prominent and respected human rights and social justice activists.
The artist has been in conversation with Public Art Fund about doing a project in New York for more than seven years, but from 2011 to 2015 his passport was confiscated, and he was arrested and detained by the Chinese authorities for his vocal political activism and criticism. We are proud to be working with him at long last to present this work, this year, in this city — a beacon for free expression and democratic ideals. 
"When I left New York in the 80s as a student, I had nothing – I could have never dreamed of this project. All these years later, the show is like a love letter to the city and its people.”
About Public Art Fund
This year, Public Art Fund is celebrating its 40th anniversary of free access to the most important art of our time, championing the role of artistic expression in an open society by bringing dynamic contemporary art to the broadest possible audiences across New York City. 
Public Art Fund has redefined what public art is and can be. Our more than 450 projects have demonstrated the power and potential of public art to transform the urban environment, engage audiences of all ages and backgrounds, and capture the imaginations of millions.
Why should I support this project?
“When the Berlin Wall fell, there were 11 countries with border fences and walls. By 2016, that number had increased to 70. We are witnessing a rise in nationalism, an increase in the closure of borders, and an exclusionary attitude towards migrants and refugees, the victims of war and the casualties of globalization.”
Ai Weiwei and Public Art Fund share a vision that art should be freely accessible to everyone and leave a lasting impact on those who experience it. Good Fences Make Good Neighbors, which will be experienced by millions of New Yorkers and visitors from across the globe, is the embodiment of that vision. 
This is a moment when it is crucial to stand up for projects that reflect our values. Join Public Art Fund, Ai Weiwei, and our champions around the world by supporting this incredible project! 
Rewards
Postcards, set of 3
Pin (1.25in x 1.25in)
T-shirt
Baggu tote
Rally-style print (16" x 20," unframed)
Rally-style prints, set of 3 (16" x 20" each, unframed)
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Even with our 40 years of experience producing ambitious and inspiring artwork, this exhibition is a huge undertaking! It’s truly a global project, with partners based on multiple continents, and myriad collaborators across NYC, including city agencies, community leaders, and site partners.
 
But we’ve always felt that in the challenge, lies the reward.
 
We’re confident that we can pull this off! As a non-profit, we rely on the support of funders of all kinds to make artists' visions a reality. Your support will help us include all of the sites that Ai Weiwei has envisioned for this show, making it a truly impactful and citywide endeavor. We know that there are enough people out there who share our vision and desire to make this exhibition happen at the scale we’ve dreamed!

----

Your pledge is tax-deductible! Where goods and services are provided by Public Art Fund in exchange for your contribution, the tax deductible amount excludes the fair market value of the goods and services provided.

----

This campaign is endorsed by an independent jury selected by Art Basel.

----

Images courtesy of Ai Weiwei studio. 
Documentary images © Human Flow / Ai Weiwei Studio.
Video by SandenWolff.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Announcing Public Art Fund's Second Kickstarter Campaign
updates.update_content:
A huge thanks to the more than 850 people who have pledged so far! Your support has helped us surpass our goal by more than 5%...and counting!
With 12 more hours until the campaign closes, there is still time to be a part of this landmark project. Please share the campaign with your friends and help us finish strong.
We are overwhelmed by the huge show of support for this exhibition and cannot thank you all enough for helping Public Art Fund make Ai Weiwei's vision for this project a reality.

updates.update_userinfo: Behind the Scenes Update – Happy New Year + Members Only Tour
updates.update_content:
This morning we hit our very ambitious $80,000 funding goal – all thanks to our incredible backers!
If you haven’t yet backed the campaign, there is still time to be a part of it. There is just under one week to go and some fantastic rewards are still available. All pledges that go above-and-beyond our funding goal will be put to very good use making this project a reality.

updates.update_userinfo: Behind the Scenes Update – Show’s Open & Share Your Story
updates.update_content:
To kick-off the weekend, we're pleased to announce that now through Tuesday, September 12 at noon (EST) we're offering several new reward levels featuring access to Ai Weiwei's talk at The Cooper Union in NYC on October 12, 2017 -- before they go on sale to the general public.
We're sure this talk will sell out fast! So reserve your priority-seating ticket by upgrading your pledge to one of the limited-time rewards today.

updates.update_userinfo: Behind the Scenes Update - Public Preview
updates.update_content:
Thank you to all those who helped us surge past the 50% funded marker last week with new and increased pledges!
We are happy to announce that (by popular demand!) we have added international shipping options to select countries for our most popular rewards, so please check back to see if we can ship to your address.
Now that we're officially halfway -- with only two more weeks to go -- we hope you'll help us keep the momentum going by sharing the campaign with your friends.

campaign.story:
UPDATE 9/14: We've announced the winners of our contest. You can read all about it on the blog. Here are the top three winners, with more finalists at the bottom of the page.
Overall winner © Oleg Zinkovetsky in Madisonville, Tennessee.
  Best Documentary (tie) © Mike Wardynski in Smith Rock State Park, Oregon.
  Best Documentary (tie) © Robert Cannon in Washington, D.C.
 UPDATE 9/12: More exciting news: We've added this beautiful in-camera double exposure of the Arthur Ravenel Bridge in Charleston, South Carolina by FStoppers.com co-founder Patrick Hall. You can read more about how Patrick created the image, here.
In-camera double exposure © Patrick Hall
 New Stretch Goal and Reward announced
If we reach our new stretch goal of $15,000, we'll be sending everyone who has pledged $20 or more a commemorative sticker based on Andrew Studer's eclipse image.
UPDATE 8/25: We're thrilled to announce that Andrew Studer's stunning image of a rock climber framed by the solar eclipse is now part of our project and will be featured in our book, Chasing the Great American Eclipse: Images and Essays from Totality. 
Andrew is also signing and numbering a limited number of 16 x 24 prints of his photo that will be included as rewards in our $500 reward tier, "The Total Eclipse Package." (The image won't be included in any of the other reward tiers). 
If there is any image that will be looked back upon years from now when people think of the Great American Eclipse of 2017, it may very well be Andrew's. You can read more about how he and his team created this image on FStoppers: http://bit.ly/2wGiKNI
© Andrew Studer in Smith Rock State Park, Oregon.
---------
© 2017 Dimitrios Manis in Madras, Oregon.
Our book will document the spectrum of emotions, the crowds, the traffic jams, the street corner preachers, the revelers and the moments that will remind us what it was like the day the sun disappeared over America.
Those who saw the total solar eclipse on Aug. 21 will tell you there's absolutely nothing that compares to watching the sun flicker to darkness in the middle of the day.
As the sky slowly went dark, the temperature dropped and people all around were gasping in amazement, screaming in delight or even becoming overcome with emotion. Psychologists say that watching a total solar eclipse can have an unsettling effect on people because, frankly, it's hard for our minds to cope with what is happening.
Chasing the Great American Eclipse captures the  spectacle of this total solar eclipse -- a once in a 100-year coast-to-coast event that was witnessed by tens of millions of people in the 70-mile wide swath of "totality."
If you are a fan of documentary and street photography, we think you'll be enthralled by this study in human nature and what it reveals about our culture. The parties and festivals, the doomsayers, the curious and the entrepreneurial spirit that these types of hyped events bring out will be on display across America.
The book will be a mix of photojournalism, street photography, visual storytelling and stunning images of the eclipse over various landscapes and cityscapes. It's sure to be a conversation starter on your coffee table and will be an interesting piece of history that you'll be able to look back upon in the years to come. 
Phases of the eclipse © Joseph Gruber in the Great Smoky Mountains.
Projects of Earth
We're also proud to be part of Kickstarter's "Projects of Earth" campaign, which honors the 40th anniversary of the Voyager spacecraft, which carried the "Golden Record" -- a collection of images, sounds and greetings that created a snapshot of life on earth. 
The Projects of Earth are things that might be placed on that Golden Record today as a record of our humanity in the 21st Century. We'd like to think that if an alien culture were to pick up a copy of Chasing the Great American Eclipse, they might learn a thing or two about man's fascination with the heavens.
© 2017 Joe Newman in Jefferson City, Missouri
How We Are Doing It
Our team of photographers was embedded in various locations on the day of the eclipse, including Oregon, Missouri, Tennessee, Georgia and South Carolina. 
The members of our team are all experienced photographers and were all contributors to our most recent photo book, UnPresidented, which documented the protests and celebration at the Trump inauguration and was successfully funded on Kickstarter.
We are also running a nationwide contest for people to submit photos for consideration. You can find the contest here.
Our jury for the contest includes veteran, award-winning photojournalists Carl Juste of the Miami Herald and André Chung, formerly of the Baltimore Sun and Jarob Ortiz, a National Park Service photographer who was once referred to as the "next Ansel Adams," Heather Goss, an editor at Air & Space magazine and Sarah Gordon, who teaches the history of photography at American University and who has curated photography exhibits at the National Gallery of Art. 
Money raised during the Kickstarter campaign will finance design and printing of the book and help defray travel expenses incurred in journeying to various locations in the path of totality.
The Editors
Shamila Chaudhary is an avid photographer whose work has been featured in The Washington Post as well as local media outlets and galleries in the Washington, D.C. metro area. Currently, she is a Senior South Asia Fellow at the Washington D.C.-based New America think tank and also a Senior Advisor at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies where she oversees special projects, communications, marketing, institutional planning, and strategic initiatives. Her work is regularly cited and published in Foreign Policy, The Washington Post, the New York Times and she has frequently appeared on CNN, BBC News America, NPR, and Fox News, CCTV, and other outlets. She also has twelve years of experience working in the U.S. government, most recently at the White House as Director for Pakistan and Afghanistan on the National Security Council from 2010-2011. She was the co-editor of the documentary photography book “UnPresidented: The Inauguration of Donald J. Trump and the People’s Response.” 
________________________________
Joe Newman is an award-winning journalist and photographer. He blogs about photography on the Huffington Post and is the editor of the photography website, Focus on the Story. His work has exhibited at several shows in DC over the past couple years, and he is currently in the Leica Store DC's "Dusk to Dawn" exhibit. He leads photography workshops in Cuba and was the co-editor and publisher of "UnPresidented: The Inauguration of Donald J. Trump and the People's Response." Before starting Cosmic Smudge Media in 2016, he directed media strategy at the Project On Government Oversight. Prior to moving to DC, he spent many years as a newspaper reporter and editor at the Orlando Sentinel, St. Petersburg Times and Palm Beach Post. At the Sentinel, he directed news coverage at the paper's largest bureau before joining the paper's Enterprise Reporting Team, where he won awards for his coverage of Florida's shifting demographics, urban design (or lack thereof), and the state's threatened environment.
© 2017 Dwight Jefferson in Nashville, Tennessee.
The Book
The hardcover book will include both black and white and full color images. The paper quality will be top notch. The number of pages and number of images in the book are TBD, but we expect the book to have somewhere between 90 and 130 pages.The physical dimensions of the book are also TBD but the longest side will be at least 10 inches long. 
Honorable Mention @ Amandala Photography / Amanda Senior in Big Summit Prairie, Oregon.
  Honorable Mention @ Amandala Photography / Amanda Senior in Big Summit Prairie, Oregon.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is the second documentary photo book project we are doing on Kickstarter. The first book, UnPresidented, taught us a lot about how to manage and fulfill a Kickstarter and how to take a book from concept to reality. 

This time around, we know what to expect -- from how much it costs to print a hardcover book to how much it costs to mail a book overseas (a lot more than we were expecting).

The biggest variable will be the quality of images we get from the contest submissions. But based on previous contests and our plans to advertise the contest heavily, we're pretty confident it will attract some high-quality images.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
I dropped off the last load of books today -- 99 percent of you should have your books either now or within the next 9 days. You should have received a tracking # in your email from Stamps.com.
The only people whose books have not gone out are the people who did not complete surveys or a few international backers who still need to get me their phone numbers.
I am flying out of the country on Saturday and will return July 5. I'll follow up with any issues then i.e. books that haven't been sent, books that haven't arrived, books damaged during shipping, etc.

The printer, Taylor Specialty Books of Dallas, finished printing the books on Saturday and shipped them out today.
At this moment, the shipment is in St. Louis. You can follow their journey to DC at this link: https://www.estes-express.com/WebApp/ShipmentTracking/
Tracking no.: 1540115756

updates.update_userinfo: Book is going to the printer today
updates.update_content:
Hello,
It has been a long and, at times, painful process but the book is headed to the printer today. This most recent delay was because of some issues with some of the photos. We had to get some of the photographers to resubmit, which took awhile to get straightened out. It also forced us to redesign some pages where we weren't able to get properly-sized photos back. There was also the general problem of the designer and I trying to do all this while juggling other projects that have since started.

Hello,
I'm back from Cuba and working with the designer to make some final edits. I'll be sending the surveys out sometime in the next couple of days. In the meantime, for full transparency, I'm providing a link below to the current draft of the book, so that you can see the "work in progress." If you download this .pdf, you'll actually be able to see notes and edits that I've inserted throughout the book.

I know that many of you are upset and angry because of the lack of communication. I realize there is no explanation that would be adequate to forgive the lack of communication. I take full responsibility for that and wish I could offer a reasonable explanation. 
The fact is, I’ve wrestled with the decision of whether to pull the plug on this project and return your pledges. While we have outstanding images for this book, it was clear to me in the fall that there were nowhere near enough from the contest entries or the ones I had commissioned that met my artistic expectations. I tried to counter this by adding essays to the book and buying the rights to some outstanding images that had not been submitted to our contest.

Chasing the Great American Eclipse: Images and Essays from Totality is going to be a reality thanks to your support! 
In the next couple of weeks, you will get a survey asking you things like your shipping address and how you want your name to be printed in our list of Kickstarter backers.
Meanwhile, we'll be doing working hard to finish selecting the images that will be included in the book, working on the design and getting it to the printer. We'll keep you updated along the way.

MARLYEEN
Washington, D.C. 20001

On August 21st, 2017, we were all surrounded by darkness as the sun blocked out the...oops, my bad. I was actually thinking of this project's creator leaving us in the dark for months and now late on delivering this book. I had a few kickstarters take my money and run in 2017. So far 2018 isn't looking much better. 8^(
@Daniel V. Although frustrated, I too hope that this comes to light. If they’ve been successful before, there’s a good chance they just aren’t too good with communication. Right?? ( crossing fingers)

I’m with you guys in wishing for an update, three months without any word, while nearing the original fulfillment date, is frustrating. However, these creators have finished another kickstarter photo book (it’s for sale on Amazon), and on their website they have several events planned in 2018, including one in January. I think it’s more likely that we are dealing with the normal delays in a Kickstarter project (almost every project runs late, if they deliver within 3-4 months of the original estimate that is ‘on time’ for most kickstarters), and possibly the creators being busy with multiple projects. I’m going to remain optimistic that eventually we will get this book, it will look great, and hopefully soon we will get an update on the production timeline.
Looks like we all got scammed on this one. Not a single update in three months. I wonder if we can call credit card company for a charge back?
Three months since last update! A little respect here!!!
Can you post an update, what is going on with your book, did it get delayed to next year?
202-445-1391. I called but got a answering machine.
It is such a beautiful project. I hope it can be realized.
The website has a phone number. I might call
Anxiously awaiting some kind of update on shipment of the book. Even if the news is not promising, an update would be much appreciated!
November 8 is the last time this creator has signed into Kickstarter. It’s a shame really. We get excited and they fall off the earth.

campaign.story:
Story
Soft lighting shines through ant tunnels at night.
I traveled 999 days on my bicycle, I crossed six continents, circling the earth twice (Travel Log). In the glow of inspiration following that journey I spent a year conceiving and building my masterpiece. It is completely strange and lovely. I call it an Ant Space, a thin habitat for ants and plants, backlit by a glowing nebula and designed to hang on a wall. It is living, evolving art.
My goal with this KickStarter campaign is to launch the Ant Space as an art piece and a product. It is a beautiful, meditative, nuanced hobby. I want to start a community around it. Backers will receive an Ant Space built by me. They will be the seeds to reach a wider audience.
Art
The backdrop of each Ant Space is a unique selection from the immaculate Hubble Space Telescope image The Carina Nebula: Star Birth In The Extreme. The composition spans fifty light years, capturing the brightest stars in the sky. It is the most beautiful of astronomical observations.
Life
Add life to the Ant Space. Plants live passively, fitting themselves seamlessly into the environment. Ants are just the opposite. They sculpt the world to meet their needs.
Watch plants above and below the soil. A reminder that roots growing down are as important as leaves growing up.
Impermanence  
In every moment tunnels and hills morph across an endlessly evolving scene. What it will be can never be known and what it has been will never be repeated. It is an artwork that exists only in the present.
Color  
Take control of the lights using a smartphone or tablet. The Ant Space becomes an instrument for the eyes. Orchestrate a show with the touch of a finger. Find intensity in the brightness, evoke a mood with the colors.
Care
Care for the life within the Ant Space. A drop of water and a pinch of sugar will nourish the ants for a week. Expect the ants to live for several months at which time there are options regarding what to do next. 
Most simply, the Ant Space may be left to exist in that final form as an attractive art piece and useful light.
More ants may be added at any time to continue digging the soil.
Plants may be given time to establish themselves before adding more ants.
Add to the scene with more layers of colored sand and soil.
The habitat can be easily taken apart then cleaned for a fresh start. 
DeepDream Background
Google's DeepDream neural network was inspired by the visual cortex. Images it produces are artifacts of a copy of a human brain. 
The Carina Nebula DeepDream background is an option for every Ant Space. From a distance it looks like a cloudy nebula, up close it is teeming with life.
Ant-scaping  
Each Ant Space is an ecosystem. Play with the life inside. The narrow habitat makes the game one of subtle manipulation. Sculpt the scene only from above. Drop in seeds and water, add more ants and colored sand. Intelligently design a complex balance of creatures and plants. The Ant Space will evolve over years as a co-creation between the life within and the hand that placed it there.
Musings 
Click the image for more musings about ants.
  Click the image to watch the full eight month time lapse.
    Click the image to immerse yourself.

updates.update_content:
Hello Backers,
The KickStarter was not funded, but I did learn from the experience. The joy of having an Ant Space comes from getting close to watch an ant run up a hill with a piece of soil, then to check again a few hours later to see how the tunnels have progressed. It is a subtle, pleasant experience that is not easy to convey over the internet. 
I am not discouraged. Ant Spaces are already making their way into the world. They are now available through my website: .

Watch the first 19 days of tunneling compressed into 10 seconds. It is fascinating. 
http://imgur.com/gallery/JyX9Qe1

A new article has been posted in Westword! 
http://www.westword.com/arts/jacob-lemanskis-ant-space-art-at-reality-garage-and-hoi-polloi-workshop-9401879

campaign.story:
*REGARDING PLEDGE LEVELS THAT INCLUDE A NAME IN THE ACKNOWLEDGMENTS: In order for Baby Tattoo to fulfill this component of the reward, each backer must complete an online questionnaire indicating the name they would like printed. The questionnaire will be sent electronically after the conclusion of the campaign. Backers who do not complete the questionnaire by the indicated cutoff date will not receive an acknowledgement.
A NOTE ABOUT THE SKY-HIGH COST OF SHIPPING: We’re dragons. We can usually get from here to there very efficiently (even when “there” is halfway around the world). Most of us can fly like the wind, but although we would love to deliver your rewards ourselves, negative stereotypes about our species make it difficult for us to venture into the public eye without causing a panic. So…
We rely mainly on the US Postal Service and their international shipping partners to get packages from our lair to your door. The price of commercial shipping has skyrocketed in recent years. We know the shipping prices that we require seem outrageous, but those are based on the real cost of packing your rewards safely and shipping them reliably (with tracking numbers). WE DO NOT MAKE A PROFIT ON SHIPPING. We are as frustrated with the high costs of delivery as you are!
There is some good news in that we try to add small extra surprise rewards into the flat rate packaging we use for most shipments – as a way of easing the pain and thanking you for your support and understanding. We are passionate about the Kickstarter community, and we will always strive to reward your generosity by exceeding your expectations in whatever ways we can.
Sincerely,

The Dragons
Artwork © 2017 Brian Kesinger
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Baby Tattoo has been publishing high-quality art editions for nearly a decade and a half. Ringmaster Bob Self and his team are really good at making gorgeous books, but the process sometimes takes longer than anticipated. What we’re trying to say is… Baby Tattoo can be slow (kind of like mermaids).

The good news is… dragons are in charge now. WE ARE NOT SLOW!

We will see to it that all dragon-centric rewards are shipped in time for Christmas 2017. Count on it. (We won’t make any guarantees about the mermaid stuff though.)
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Interested in what's going on in the land of Baby Tattoo? Join Brian Kesinger and Ringmaster Bob for a live, interactive "Ask Us Anything" video chat via Zoom at 6:00 PM Pacific Time on Thursday, August 27th, 2020. We'll be discussing the status of the 'Time Traveling With Your Octopus' book, what the book production process is like, and anything else you might have on your mind. 
Zoom Meeting ID (click to join): 818 7487 6039

updates.update_userinfo: Return to "Dragons vs. Mermaids Surprise Rematch"
updates.update_content:
Hopefully this will be the conclusory update in what will likely become known as the Time Traveling Octopus Meets Dragons vs. Mermaids trilogy. 
Yesterday's premature Robots vs. Witches campaign has been sent back to the future (where it belongs), causing the equally mis-timestamped Dragons vs. Mermaids campaign to boomerang back into existence from its day-before-yesterday prominence. One more day should see it back in the past (where it belongs).
But while the ghosts of dragons and mermaids past have been haunting the Time Traveling Octopus campaign for a few hours, they've generously added a bonus reward to Levels 3 and 4. Either a Dragons vs. Mermaids or an Otto & Victoria bookmark will be selected at random and included in each of these trilogy book set bundles. You can read all about it in the most recent .

Remember how yesterday a girl and her pet cephalopod broke Kickstarter and caused Baby Tattoo and Brian Kesinger's current Time Traveling Octopus campaign to be semi-co-opted into a vague variant of the 2017 Dragons vs. Mermaids campaign?
Surprise...
Today that same project has apparently fast forwarded to 2020 and become a sequel titled [Robots vs. Witches] vs. [Dragons vs. Mermaids]. For real (for the moment)! Check out whatever this next-iteration mixed-and-matched mishmash project is by clicking .

Remember when Baby Tattoo and Brian Kesinger launched a Kickstarter campaign for a dragon sketchbook? Remember how a bunch of renegade dragons hacked the campaign? Remember how some angry mermaids staged a hostile takeover? Remember how it all turned out to be a P.R. stunt?
If you thought things couldn't get any stranger, have we got an update for you!
Stop us if you've heard this one before... A time traveling Victorian woman-about-town and her pet land octopus have broken Kickstarter and caused Baby Tattoo and Brian Kesinger's current campaign to transform into a chronologically corrupted  campaign which has now undergone some sort of intra-Kickstarter backslide to degenerate into an imperfect clone of the 2017 campaign!

updates.update_content:
Greetings, Baby Tattoo enthusiasts!
We'd like to let you know about a project by Mac Beauvais, a close ally of Brian Kesinger's and longtime Victoria cosplayer.

Ringmaster Bob here with a quick update to let everyone know we’ve just launched two new book campaigns!
One, “When Is High Moon?” is a graphic novel anthology created by moonlighting artists from the story and visual development departments at Walt Disney Animation Studios. Featuring work by John Musker, Brian Kesinger, Brittney Lee, and more, this passion project reflects on the question "When Is High Moon?".
PLAY
