campaign.story:
Enemy Kitchen is a public art project by Michael Rakowitz that explores the relationship between hospitality and hostility. Rakowitz and his mother collected and compiled recipes from the Baghdad area. These recipes are turned into dishes which are served by U.S. veterans of the Iraq War from a food truck designed by the artist.  
The Enemy Kitchen project began in 2003 in New York City as a way for food to spark dialogue around Iraq in new ways, ultimately taking form as a food truck.
In storage since its last food service in 2012, the food truck has been victim to theft, graffiti, and other damage. We want to restore and repair the truck, bring it up to code, and park it on the front plaza of the MCA Chicago, where it will serve free food for the local community during pop-up activations during the exhibition.
Enemy Kitchen will be a key part of Michael Rakowitz: Backstroke of the West, a major exhibition and the artist’s first U.S. museum survey, which will open at the MCA on September 16, 2017.
Why is this Important?
Sharing a meal or a recipe is something that everyone can experience, no matter where they are in the world. Likewise, art has the power to connect people across geography, language, and culture. Bringing these two elements together, Enemy Kitchen will allow people to support, access, and experience a Middle Eastern food culture that was (and is still) disrupted by the Iraq War.
What will your contributions support? 
As the MCA prepared for Michael Rakowitz: Backstroke of the West, it was clear that Enemy Kitchen was an important part of his art career and had to be a part of the exhibition. But there was a problem. After Enemy Kitchen’s last food service in 2012 the truck was put into storage in the parking lot of Babylon, a restaurant in North Chicago. Despite being locked up, the truck was broken into, stolen from, and vandalized with messages of hate. Mechanically the vehicle would not start, aesthetically it was damaged, and wasn’t up to preparing or serving food—Enemy Kitchen’s situation was dire. 
If we work together, we can put Enemy Kitchen back on the road, bring it up to city code for working food trucks, and restore it as an artwork. This campaign will also support a full schedule of free community events where the truck will serve Iraqi cuisine to the public, for free.
Why Kickstarter? 
By pairing with Kickstarter, the MCA hopes to reach a larger audience for Michael Rakowitz’s art and ideas— even if you cannot visit the truck or taste the food created there, you can make a meal using the Enemy Kitchen recipe cards or while wearing the apron and support the dialogue created around some of the most pressing issues our world faces. In this way the MCA is creating a forum for the public to interact with the artwork itself, no matter where they are since preparing and eating the meals is essential to the artwork itself.
Kickstarter Rewards
As thanks for supporting the project, Kickstarter backers can receive a variety of rewards connected to Enemy Kitchen. Preview the rewards here; as some rewards are currently being created, not all rewards are shown but we will update as they are produced. 
 Saddam Hussein Replica Paperware 5-pack: $15 or more
 Meal Ticket and Museum Admission for One: $25 or more
 "Backstroke of the West" Catalog: $35 or more
 "Bless Your Hands" Kubba Spoon: $35 or more
Sabreen: Live in Jerusalem LP: $60 or more
 Enemy Kitchen Apron and Recipes: $75 or more
 Chicago-Iraqi Flag: $2,500 or more
 Shopping Trip with Michael Rakowitz: $5,000 or more
About Michael Rakowitz  
Based in Chicago, Iraqi-American artist Michael Rakowitz (b. 1973) makes work that explores recent contested social, political, and cultural histories. Drawing on personal experiences and research on these subjects, as well as history and popular culture, Rakowitz creates illustrated objects, installations, and performances that invite viewers to contemplate their complicit relationship to the political world around them, recognizing that hospitality and hostility are interlinked.
About the MCA Chicago
The Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago (MCA) is one of Chicago’s major museums and one of the nation’s largest facilities devoted to the art of our time. The MCA is an artist-activated and audience-engaged contemporary art museum. We generate art, ideas, and conversation around the creative process. We are a cultural leader of local necessity and international distinction.
This campaign is endorsed by an independent jury selected by Art Basel.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Kickstarter community support will be essential in the complete restoration of Enemy Kitchen and a full schedule of free food service events for the community on the MCA Plaza. Without the support of the Kickstarter backers, we will have to pare back the free community events to a bare minimum. 

Many of the rewards have been produced already and are currently in Michael Rakowitz's collection, or they can be reproduced easily since they would take the form of a work created in the past. The MCA will be responsible for administering the rewards which will be shipped as speedily as possible.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

support.title: Enemy Kitchen Supporter!
support.descp: Thanks so much for your support from the MCA Chicago and Michael Rakowitz! Backers at this level receive exclusive behind-the-scenes updates as the Enemy Kitchen rolls out on the streets of Chicago. Plus, your name will be included on a list of backers on the MCA website.

support.title: Video Tour and Enemy Kitchen Recipes
support.descp: Get a look at the MCA’s presentation of “Michael Rakowitz: Backstroke of the West” from anywhere with this video tour of the exhibition, made available only to Kickstarter backers at this level. We’ll also provide digital recipes from the Enemy Kitchen. These Baghdadi recipes were collected by Michael Rakowitz with the help of his mother, and we’ll send them to you to enjoy and share with friends and family.

support.title: Saddam Hussein Replica Paperware 5-Pack
support.descp: As part of his project ‘Spoils’ (2011), Michael Rakowitz prepared a meal served on fine china looted from Saddam Hussein’s palace. In reference to this work and what it means to dine with an “Enemy,” food from the Enemy Kitchen is served on paperware replicas of Saddam Hussein’s china. Backers at this level receive a 5-pack of paper plates that looks like Hussein's china for their own collection and use.

support.title: Meal Ticket and Museum Admission for One
support.descp: Food service from the Enemy Kitchen Food Truck is free to the public. This meal ticket secures your priority place for one service and grants complementary admission to all the exhibitions at the MCA Chicago. Visit the Enemy Kitchen Food Truck and see the exhibition “Michael Rakowitz: Backstroke of the West” in the same day!

support.title: "Backstroke of the West" Catalog
support.descp: This publication documents the exhibition at the MCA, which is Michael Rakowitz’s first museum survey. The catalog is a retrospective of Rakowitz’s work and includes writings from MCA Manilow Senior Curator Omar Kholeif.

support.title: Meal Ticket and Museum Admission for Two
support.descp: Same as the above ($25 level), but this package reserves two meals and admission to the MCA Chicago to be enjoyed by you and a friend.

support.title: Sabreen: Live In Jerusalem LP
support.descp: This vinyl LP was recorded and created in tangent with Michael Rakowitz’s artwork “The Breakup” 2010—a ten-part radio series commissioned for Radio Amwaj in Ramallah, Palestine. The Breakup considers the intricacies of The Beatles’ 1969 disbanding as an example of a collaboration that grinds to a halt amid unraveling negotiations and failed communication. Only 500 were printed on blue color vinyl. Includes a magazine-style track listing and poster.

support.title: Enemy Kitchen Apron and Recipes
support.descp: Look the part of an Enemy Kitchen chef with a custom-made chef’s apron. Prominently displaying the Enemy Kitchen’s iconic eagle logo, this reward was made in limited supply for backers at this level. Also included are the Enemy Kitchen recipe cards to try at home.

support.title: Enemy Kitchen Experience Package
support.descp: At this level you will receive the custom Enemy Kitchen apron, all the recipe cards, plus a meal ticket and museum admission for one. Enjoy all the Enemy Kitchen has to offer with thanks from the MCA!

support.title: Invitation to Curator-led Tour
support.descp: A contribution at this level secures your attendance (plus one) to a curator-led tour of “Michael Rakowitz: Backstroke of the West”. Visit the exhibition and learn about the retrospective of Michael Rakowitz’s work in an intimate setting with an MCA Staff Curator.

support.title: Dinner Reception and Signed Catalog
support.descp: For this generous gift, the MCA will open an invitation for you and one guest to a formal dinner and reception with MCA donors and Michael Rakowitz prior to the opening of “Backstroke of the West”. The MCA will also include an exhibition catalog signed by Michael.

support.title: Chicago-Iraqi Flag
support.descp: Own a piece of the artwork! For each Enemy Kitchen event, the staff will fly this custom-made Chicago flag made in Iraqi colors over the food truck. You could own this signature part of the Enemy Kitchen.

support.title: Shopping Trip with Michael Rakowitz
support.descp: Backers at this level will be invited to a one-of-a-kind shopping trip at the Devon Market, a Middle Eastern grocery in the North Chicago area, led by Michael Rakowitz. Donors will get to meet Michael at the market and share in some of his favorite Middle Eastern products and recipes.

support.title: Enemy Kitchen Recipe Cards
support.descp: Get all the recipes from the Enemy Kitchen printed and delivered to you on custom card stationary featuring the Enemy Kitchen logo.

support.title: "Bless Your Hands" Kubba Spoon
support.descp: As a way of thanking his mother for her help preparing the recipes, Michael Rakowitz had a Kubba spoon made for her with the Arabic inscription “Bless Your Hands”. In Iraq, it is customary to say this phrase to a chef when you have enjoyed their meal. The MCA has a made a limited run of replicas to share the phrase and tradition with our backers on Kickstarter.

support.title: Meal Ticket and Museum Admission for Two
support.descp: Same as the above ($25 level), but this package reserves two meals and admission to the MCA Chicago to be enjoyed by you and a friend.

updates.update_userinfo: A Final Thanks for Your Support
updates.update_content:
The MCA Chicago and Enemy Kitchen team would like to offer one final thanks to our backers on Kickstarter for your support of this campaign. We are honored you could join us in this project in so many ways—by making a meal from Michael’s recipes, wearing the Enemy Kitchen apparel, or a sharing in food and community on the MCA plaza.

This week, Artnet published a great recap of last fall’s events and interviewed Michael Rakowitz. You can read more of that article here.

will be on display at the MCA until March 4, 2018. We hope you can take the opportunity to visit it.

From all of us at the MCA, Enemy Kitchen, and Michael Rakowitz:

Hello Enemy Kitchen Supporters! We are so happy to announce we have finished production of backer rewards and we are ready to begin shipping.  

If you have not done so already, please fill out your backer survey. You can also make changes to the address you have already provided us if it has changed recently. This is all done by logging into your Kickstarter account.

We plan to begin shipping in 48 hours. No worries if you can’t respond in time. The MCA’s fulfillment team will be reaching out to non-responses through e-mail. We’ll do our best to make sure everyone gets their reward as soon as possible.

Thanks again from the whole Enemy Kitchen team! We’re delighted to be able to share this project with you.

updates.update_userinfo: RESCHEDULED: Enemy Kitchen Food Service for 9/29
updates.update_content:
The MCA Chicago has rescheduled the Enemy Kitchen food service for Friday, September 29. There will be no food service on this day. Service will now occur on Sunday, October 1 at 2 p.m. instead.  

For those of you who were sent meal tickets and museum admission for the September 29 service—your previous ticket is still considered valid, and you can present it on Sunday, October 1 for the same service. You have also been sent a new voucher, which you can print and use as well.

It was so great to see such a fantastic turnout for the first meal service of Enemy Kitchen on the MCA Chicago plaza! The first service was presented on the same afternoon as the public opening of “Michael Rakowitz: Backstroke of the West”, which is now on view at the MCA. We’re so grateful to everyone who helped make this project possible. Thank you!  
If you wanted to attend a meal service from Enemy Kitchen, there are still four more chances to do so. Dates of services are below. More information is available on the MCA’s Calendar. 
Friday, September 22 at 6 p.m.

Thanks to the generous support of our backers, we are thrilled to announce we have successfully raised $30,000 towards our goal! We did it!

We are so excited for what’s to come. Funds raised through Kickstarter will pay for the refurbishment of the Enemy Kitchen food truck and support free food services on the MCA Plaza. Additional funds raised will go towards adding extra food services at the MCA. Contributions can be made until 6 p.m. central time today when the campaign closes!

Everyone’s contributions, both large and small, made such a significant impact to restart this important cultural project and share it with an audience in Chicago and around the world. All of us at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago and Michael Rakowitz want to say

updates.update_userinfo: About 48 Hours Left to Back with Matching Gifts!
updates.update_content:
With just under 48 hours left to go in our Kickstarter we are just 7% away from our goal. To help us get to 100% funded and beyond, a generous MCA Donor has offered to match all gifts made by backers from now until near the end of the campaign! By supporting us now, or by increasing your pledge, you can double your impact.

We're asking everyone to share this project with their friends online to help get the word out, posting to Facebook and Twitter would really help and you never know who might be a fan of Middle Eastern cuisine and culture. Or, if you can, please consider chipping in a little more—if each of our backers contributed $5 or more we would meet our goal.

Highlighted below are rewards for Kickstarter backers we have created to bring Michael’s art and ideas to a wider audience, and can be enjoyed by those unable to visit the Enemy Kitchen on the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago’s public plaza. They’re also a great way to commemorate being a part of Enemy Kitchen!  

$25 or More: Enemy Kitchen Recipe Cards  
Michael Rakowitz developed these traditional Baghdadi recipes with the help of his Iraqi mother. This tier offers backers copies of these original recipes to be used and adapted to individual taste and skill. Backers at this level can experience the food of Enemy Kitchen from anywhere and for years to come.

updates.update_userinfo: Own a Part of the Art Work: Enemy Kitchen Flag
updates.update_content:
Michael Rakowitz designed this flag to hang off Enemy Kitchen during its first food services. As part of conceptualizing the project as a food truck and providing staffing, Michael tapped into the often overlooked Iraqi community in Chicago. The iconic four-starred Chicago flag has had its usual red stars and blue bars replaced with the red, black, and green of the Iraqi flag. In doing so, the flag becomes a symbol of the joining of cultures of the Iraqi refugees and the city where they reside.

For each food service on the MCA plaza, a unique flag will be flown with the truck and preserved after its service. This reward was created so that part of the Enemy Kitchen could be permanently collected as an artwork. As a work of art, Enemy Kitchen exists primarily as a public piece, relying on community interaction—taking and enjoying food—for its context. The Enemy Kitchen flag is the closet approximation to taking home the experience as a work of art that can be made available for collection.

Friends,  

We wanted to share with you our deepest regards and thank you for supporting Enemy Kitchen on Kickstarter. Thanks to your generosity we can announce we have passed 50% of our funding goal!    
It means so much to us to give new life to Enemy Kitchen and share it with a broader audience at MCA Chicago and abroad. Thank you.

campaign.story:
"Yalla Habibi - Living with War in Aleppo"
How can people actually live in a war zone?
This question may have crossed your mind if you have seen the countless news images of the destruction in the city of Aleppo. I myself and the people around me have experienced living with that war in Aleppo first hand.
With the photobook „Yalla Habibi – Living with War in Aleppo“ I want to give recognition to people in Eastern Aleppo who have continued their everyday lives with resilience and inventiveness amidst perilous circumstances. The pictures from my hometown, taken between 2013 and 2015, capture moments of the conflicting and contrasting experiences and emotions of these people. Anger, joy, grieve, fear, adventurousness, desperation, determination, solidarity, defiance, fatigue, excitement – having to live with war all of these emotions can change in an instant. The book shows people balancing the horrors of war with a sense of normalcy and trying to retain their dignity.
Through your backing I intend to produce a high quality photobook that not only generates empathy but also provokes a reflection on justice, responsibility, and human dignity.
“Yalla Habibi” – “Come on my dear” as people would say in Arabic!
    Who am I? And what is my motivation?
 „The truth is the first victim of war. Hosam Katan refused to believe this, he simply did not accept it – not for the people in his hometown.“ (Frank-Walter Steinmeier, former Foreign Minister of Germany)
"Yalla Habibi" is also part of my own story. Growing up in Aleppo I could never have imagined that one day war would break out in my country. It was when I had just turned 17 in 2011 that I experienced the beginning of the protests against the Assad regime. I saw people with a genuine believe in a Syrian revolution to establish democracy and more freedom in their country. When the regime answered protests with brute force, I decided to pick up my camera. I felt the responsibility to document what was happening around me. I started to work at the newly founded Aleppo Media Center, a network of independent local media activists. As many international news organizations were pulling out of the country for security reasons, I realized the importance to not let the events and people in Aleppo go unseen. Security has also been an issue for my work and in May 2015 I almost ran out of luck. I was shot by a sniper of the regime. After treatment in Turkey, however, I returned to Aleppo and continued my life and work there until the end of 2015.
  More than 1200 of my photographs have been distributed by the news agency Reuters from 2013. They have been published in the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, Stern magazine, and numerous other media outlets. With this photobook I want to transcend the fleeting realm of daily news coverage and present a nuanced, multilayered and in-depth view on the conflict.
I am currently studying photojournalism at Hannover University in Germany to develop my craft as a photographer. I am committed to continue my work as a photojournalist, and I hope I will be able to return to Syria in the future.
Hosam Katan. Aleppo
Why is this book important now?
Hasn’t the fighting in Aleppo stopped since the end of 2016?
“Without me in power you will have no safety and no life.” The city of Aleppo has been divided between a Western part controlled by the regime and an Eastern part largely controlled by opposition forces between 2012 until the end of 2016. In the Eastern part of Aleppo the Assad regime made its message loud and clear by the means of snipers, incarcerations, torture, artillery shelling, bombings, as well as the deprivation of basic resources like food, medicine, electricity, or education.
Yet, men, women, and children in Eastern Aleppo refused to have their lives stripped away. That is what has impressed me the most. Most of them made the conscious decision to continue living in their home city no matter what the circumstances.
  “So called ‚rebels’“, “terrorists“, “human shields“, “victims” or “civilians,” many labels have been applied to people in Eastern Aleppo. But who are the human beings behind these labels? Let’s put faces to these labels. Let’s reveal the human beings behind it. It is true that most people who are portrayed in my photographs do not or rather cannot live in Eastern Aleppo anymore. They have not vanished from the Earth though. They have been displaced from their homes as have many other Syrians.
The civil war in Syria demonstrates how the line between what is just and what is unjust is too often determined by those in power. The book, therefore, aims to be a testimony for those who neither possess effective political nor military power but who nonetheless exert incredible strength and do possess agency.
Although the news coverage of the conflict in Syria, and especially from Aleppo, has waned, it is important to keep up the dialogue because the conflict is far from being over. It cannot go unseen. People of Eastern Aleppo cannot go unseen.
  The photobook & the current status
With 152 pages, this high quality photobook will include 85 carefully selected photographs with descriptions in English. For some photos background stories about the people portrayed or about specific living conditions and people’s strategies of dealing with them will be provided. The photographs will be further contextualized by an essay of German war correspondent Carsten Stormer (author of "Die Schatten des Morgenlandes: Die Gewalt im Nahen Osten und warum wir uns einmischen müssen") and an essay by myself about my life and work in Aleppo.
Most of “Yalla Habibi” has already been rendered into the final layout. I’m happy that I could win the renowned German publishing house Kehrer for my project. If this project reaches its funding goal the book will be off to the printer for proofing, and Kehrer has agreed to publish the book in October 2017. You will, therefore, not have to wait for long to hold a copy of the book in your hands.
Yalla Habibi, book
  I also feel lucky that the maquette of my photobook has recently been awarded the PX3 Prix de la Photographie Paris 2017 (category: Professional Book, Documentary - Silver).
Book Details
format: 240 x 320 mm (9.5 x 12.6 inch)
hardcover with printed cover
152 pages
85 color photographs
language: English
retail price: 40 €
essays: Carsten Stormer, Hosam Katan
If you have any questions don´t hesitate to send me a personal message to the following email-address: hosam.abo.fesal@gmail.com
To see more of my work you can also refer to my website: www.hosamkatan.com
Why crowdfunding?
In the last 8 months, I have spent all my energy and money to release this project. Funding the actual production of the photobook (printing, binding, distribution) unfortunately exceeded my budget. That´s why I need your backing. Your entire funding will go to the production of the photobook. And I´m confident to finally release this project through your collective effort.
Beside your financial support I would also appreciate if you could spread the word about this campaign among your friends, family, colleagues and social media platforms.
Thank you so much for your support!
Rewards for your support
Every single of your contributions carries this project one step further on its way to finally materialize. In order to also materialize my gratitude and appreciation I have crafted reward packages for you containing items and experiences of which some are pictured below. They are designed to, first of all, share the finished book that you have helped to realize as well as single prints of the photographs. Some rewards give you exclusive insights into the development of the project and into my work.
But most importantly, I also see this campaign as a way to engage with you. This project is about creating a dialogue about the ongoing conflict in Syria and how people are dealing with it. So let’s keep up the dialogue together! 
Due to the size and the weight of the book and the size of the larger prints I had to add a contribution to the shipping costs for orders from outside of Germany. I have kept this contribution as low as possible while making sure that you will receive your copies and the prints in an impeccable condition. Shipping inside Germany will be free. 
      You need credentials?
I am very grateful that a large number of photos that will be included in the book have been awarded several prizes, and that I had the opportunity to share and discuss my work at several exhibitions and presentations.
        Awards
Ian Parry Special Award 2014 & the Ian Parry Award 2015 (category: highly commended)
annual Andrei Stenin International Press Photo Contest 2015
grand price at the IAFOR Documentary Photography Award 2015
Nannen Preis for journalism 2016 (category: special award)
photography award at the University of Art and Design in Offenbach 2016
PX3 Prix de la Photographie Paris 2017 (category: Professional Book, Documentary - Silver & Professional Press, War - Bronze)
Exhibitions (selection)
Ian Parry Exhibition, 2015 (London, England)
„Guerre en contraste“, 2016 (Aix-en-Provence, France)
Museum of Modern Art, 2016 (Frankfurt, Germany)
„Les enfants d’Alep“, 2016 (Marseille, France)
„Humans of Syria: Stories of daily life and survival“, 2016 (California, USA)
Ostrava Photo festival, 2017 (Ostrava, Czech Republic)
Presentations & Workshops (selection)
Aix-Marseille University, 2016 (Aix-en-Provence, France)
Deutsche Börse Photography Foundation, 2016 (Frankfurt, Germany)
Institute for Interdisciplinary Research on Conflict and Violence, 2017 (Bielefeld, Germany)
World Press Photo Exhibition, 2017 (Willy-Brandt-Haus Berlin, Germany)
Workshop on smartphone photography, organized by the German Association for Photography, 2016 (Deutsche Gesellschaft für Photographie e.V., Mannheim, Germany)
In the press
„gripping, vivid, personal“ (German Missions in the United States)
„With his feeling for the right moment, Hosam Katan creates impressive images from the perspective of an immediate observer that go beyond the pure documentation of events.“ (Deutsche Börse Photography Foundation)
„His pictures are oppressive, full of sympathy and devoid of facile voyeurism. (…) These photographs send out an appeal to all those involved in this process: shoulder your share of responsibility to finally put an end to the killing and the suffering in Syria! We owe that to people like Hosam Katan, the last photographer of Aleppo!” (Frank-Walter Steinmeier, former Foreign Minister of Germany)
"Amid Rubble, Reminders of Daily Life in Aleppo“ (Photo Journal, Wall Street Journal)
„Die Fotografien des Autodidakten zählen zu den eindringlichsten Zeugnissen des unerbittlichen Kampfes um Syriens einstige Wirtschaftsmetropole Aleppo.“ (Der Westen)
"Kriegsfotografie in Syrien. Von den Straßen Aleppos" (F.A.Z.)
„Véritables fenêtres ouvertes sur la Syrie, les clichés révèlent par leurs sujets et esthétiques une humanité partagée, universelle.“ (Guerre en contraste)
In this short German reportage filmed by the NDR you can see me preparing the book: NDR DAS! Hosam Katan - Kriegsfotograf aus Aleppo DAS!, Author: Marie Teresa Giese
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Although everything is set to go, there might be a risk that the production of the book may be delayed for some unforseen reason. In this case I will send you a notification. Moreover, if for another unforeseen reason the book will not materialize, you will of course receive all your money back.



Thank you very much for your help!
Whether you have pledged or helped to spread the word, your support means a lot!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Thank you all for your patience! Although it has been a little quiet on the Kickstarter campaign site, behind the scenes it has been anything but quiet. The publishing house Kehrer and I have been working to take the „Yalla Habibi“ photobook project from good to great. The success of the Kickstarter campaign and your feedback compelled me even more to make the best book possible. And especially the fact that your contributions exceeded the funding goal made it possible to further elevate the quality of the photobook.
1. Publication

… well ok, as of today 12:40 p.m. (CEST) the “Yalla Habibi” campaign has come to an end. Within a 30 day period 342 of you wonderful people contributed EUR 20.868 (wow!) to steer “Yalla Habibi” forward. The end of the campaign, therefore, signifies the beginning of an intense time of settling all final details so that the book can be printed at the end of September and be available to you and the world in October. I will keep you updated on the progress!
Thank you for believing in “Yalla Habibi” and the cause behind it! Your support has dispelled all doubts that people wouldn't be willing to see, read and actually buy a whole book on everyday life in conflict-ridden Aleppo/Syria. Your contributions and feedback are making me even more confident – and hopeful ...

My friends,
In a little bit more than two weeks “Yalla Habibi” has reached its funding goal of EUR 15.000! Do you feel as excited, stunned and humbled about this as I do? “Yalla Habibi. Living with War in Aleppo” will definitely publish. All these single pictures and pages will come together in one photo book!

My friends!
Our 200st backer has just joined the project and carried “Yalla Habibi” over the threshold of EUR 11.000! As you know Kickstarter is all or nothing, and this brings us a big step closer to all.
I have been listening to your feedback. So over the last week, I have made small adjustments to the rewards. The Syrian dinner is now available throughout Germany. You are invited to my place in Hannover or I will gladly visit you! It’s your choice. Besides that, I have added a package of three „Yalla Habibi“ copies to the rewards earlier last week (Some of you already took advantage of this.). If you have any further feedback on the rewards or the campaign in general, feel free to contact me or to comment.

Habibis,
After only 8 days we have pushed the „Yalla Habibi“ campaign halfway towards its funding goal, or actually a tiny bit more than halfway! I know I am saying this a lot, but well ...
Thank you so much to all of you in (no particular order by the way) Syria, Germany, Turkey, France, the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada, Israel, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Belgium, the Netherlands, Austria, Switzerland, Italy, Poland, Slovenia, Denmark, Sweden, Norway, South Korea, Hong Kong, Japan, Taiwan, and all the other countries and regions from which you have been sending your support so far!

Habibis, 
As of just now you are part of a backer community of 100 supporters who have contributed to the "Yalla Habibi" project. I cannot thank you enough for your pledges, for sharing, for your comments and your messages. I'm touched to see that so many people from different countries and different walks of life are contributing to "Yalla Habibi". I hope that more people will join this community in the upcoming days so that our joint efforts will come to fruition. Together we can make it happen!

campaign.story:
We're Loren and Susanna, the curators behind the project feminisms, which explores expressions of feminism, away from western expressions, which we feel, can often be discriminatory to women outside of its own comprehension of emancipation and empowerment.
Our fundamental aim is for this to be the first of an ongoing series of exhibitions and happenings that explore a multiplicity of different female identities that have felt excluded from feminism in the past.
Rising Islamophobia in our current political climate (need we say more than Trump and Brexit?) led us to make the decision to centre our first show around the self-expressed identities of women from the Arab and Muslim diaspora. 
We felt that brands and institutions who spoke up for women during the rise of Trump, did not actively speak up for the ethnic minorities whose livelihoods are and were threatened by these right wing tendencies.
Feminist practice has come a long way fighting for female emancipation but lacks inclusion of women from the non-western world. This exhibition is a response to the need for engaging with the multiplicity of difference in order to highlight the fundamental fact that exclusion of ethnic difference is ignorant and a danger to all of us.
Women of colour often speak of feeling excluded from the discourse of feminism because western ideals of female emancipation are the ideals placed onto women around the world. The term feminism itself has become bound in these problematics when it should speak for all the varied expressions of female emancipation. The added “s” to feminism, accordingly, symbolises this importance of engaging with pluralities of expression akin to the practice of intersectional feminism. Women are the many, not a monolith and it is the objective of Feminisms to demonstrate this. The exhibition focuses on communication and collaboration. It is our intention to question and to open up ideas difference rather than providing absolute answers, which in the past, have only caused more issues by excluding the lived experience of actual people.
We have amazing female artists working in collaboration with us who through varying multidisciplinary ways, some more literal and others more abstractly explore identity formation and articulation, both as women of the 21st century and as women who identify with the Arab & Muslim diasporas.  
Feminisms x The Arab and Muslim Diaspora will take place with your help between the 24th and 26th of August 2017 at Protein Studios in Shoreditch, London.
The exhibition will include a private view on Thursday evening, with free entry for all. Please note: registration is required to ensure we can fit you all in.
Protein Studios, Shoreditch
The show will include film work, photography, sculpture, installation and projections. We will work to ensure all of our backers receive documentation of the event including the opening night and installation shots of the works so that those of you who are unable to attend still get a chance to see what you have supported!
The confirmed artists for the exhibition (with more in conversation):
Maïmouna Guerresi 
Our first confirmed artist for the show explores Islamic faith as a converted Muslim woman through multimedia works exploring the natural and the fantastic with spiritual connotations. 
Maïmouna Guerressi - Montagne Nere
 Yumna Al-Arashi
Yumna, a photographer of Yemeni and Egyptian heritage, who grew up in the U.S explores identity and relationships to faith, displacement and belonging in varying ways, often with strong political undertones. We are extremely excited to have the opportunity to show her latest and first foray into film, Shedding Skin. 
Yumna Al-Arashi, Northern Yemen
  Lilian Nejatpour 
Lilly Nejat, is a British Iranian artist who graduated from Goldsmiths last year. Working conceptually she is currently interested in exploring the ways in which the digital feeds into our identities. We have been in conversations about a potential installation that is a response to her own interaction with her faith and technology. 
Lilian Nejatpour
Sanaa Hamid
Sanaa Hamid has in the past done a Kickstarter funded project named "My Body is Not your Battleground" where she explored the realities of growing up as a young woman in Pakistan. The specifics works we will be using are still being discussed, but all of her works confidently resonate with our intent to explore the personal and how it reflects in the communicative. 
Sanaa Hamid, My Body is Not Your Battlefield
  Maha Alasaker
With projects using the hashtag #ResistanceisFemale, Maha's work undoubtedly resonates with our insistence on the fact that resistance can come from women being stereotypically determined as passive. 
Maha Alasaker, Belonging
                   Furthermore, we are both keen to explore art events away from the gallery circuit, given that this project underlying intentions are socially engaged, it needs to engage with wider audiences.
It is however costly to use such a space, and through working with artists from so many corners of the world, the shipping of art works and regular production costs from printing, to framing, and constructing items for installations, all add up very quickly.
24th August -  Evening Private View including drinks reception
25th August - A Panel talk which will hopefully be led by the wonderfully articulate Yumna Al-Arashi, along with other artists and thinkers within the field to further the critique we are trying to generate. 
26th August - (Not yet confirmed) Zine making workshop to promote collaborative and non-corporately structured creative processes
27th August - Ticketed screening of 'Persepolis' at Moth Club's 'Deeper into Movies'. All proceeds will go to a charity related to our cause. 
This project is very close to our hearts; we have been working on it to explore how we can work collaboratively in visual culture and art to diminish discrimination and stereotyping views of particular identities.
As aspirational curators and thinkers within the visual and academic fields, we feel the urgency to organise in a way that moves beyond party politics. 
The visual realm can prove to be a powerful tool for activism, and we see this project as one that encourages an exploration of difference in dialogue. For us, dialogue is the essential tool for opening up the closed minds that still pervade our supposedly liberal society.
The space, Protein Studios in East London's Shoreditch, allows for us to engage with various audiences, from those who typically seek out art events and those who are interested in the cultures we are exploring, to those who usually attend Protein's various pop ups and culturally rich events.
Protein has a rich history of working with great brands and hosting some incredible events including "Signed For Syria" and BBH's "She Lights Up the Night". Furthermore Protein's high profile as an innovative creative agency in the centre of London's creative hub make them a great space to be collaborating with, the location means we will gain a footfall that is outside of our projected audience but the space is also has an incredible in its size and scope, allowing us to place a large number of artists together in a group show. 
Furthermore, we are both keen to explore art events away from the gallery circuit, given that this project underlying intentions are socially engaged, it needs to engage with wider audiences.
It is however costly to use such a space, and through working with artists from so many corners of the world, the shipping of art works and regular production costs from printing, to framing, and constructing items for installations, all add up very quickly.
Financial breakdown:
£1000 agreed fee for hiring Protein Studios for the three days.
£300 production costs for printing posters, exhibition booklets, stickers and leaflets to market the exhibition and to give back to our backers. 
£200 for organising a catering service which we're hoping is a particular chef focusing on palestinian food to essentuate the act of giving and inviting in.
£100 for any installational material to put the exhibition up/electronic material for exhibtion 
£100 to build and create material for our reading corner to be held during the exhibition to include academia within the exhibition contex
£300 to compensate artists for materials, production, as well as travel to the exhibition and panel talk for our London based artists.
This is a non-profit project, for the artists and us as curators and therefore all donations through this campaign will go to being able to actualise this and to paying for space and production costs. Because we will not sell any of the art works - to essentialise the importance of the message rather than any profit - our compensation to our amazing artists would come from you allowing us to pay for all production costs that they will encounter.
Going above our goal would result in being able to make the exhibition even stronger, compensating our artists more, as well as a potential starter for the next exhibition of the project.
They are all doing this for the importance of the cause but it's difficult being an artist and doing things for free and we want to make sure they are not left in a difficult situation.
Please feel free to email us any questions/ideas/critique - we are here to open up discussion and contestation and we want to make this the best it can possibly be!
Your help would be eternally appreciated. We hope this message and the ideas that shaped this exhibition can allow us to move beyond the ways in which our society is moving away from inclusion and equality for all, which should be the fundamental values that determine humanity in our global society.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The actualisation of the exhibition is inevitably challenging in terms of organising the multidisciplinary approaches that this show is working with, for example, the careful way we need to consider the use of sound and images, in a way that invites the audience to think with and communicate with us rather than being passive spectators. This is something we are continuously working with and all the artists' work has been carefully selected to create an almost utopian landscape where all these works meet and despite differing in so many ways complement each other and produce a unique dialogue.

As with any exhibition or project with a physical event which here is the three-day exhibition, things can happen last minute that complicates things. However, we are surrounded with helpful loving people all passionate about this project and happy to jump in at any point to help us if needed. Additionally, with the support of Protein as a sponsor for the event and with both of us having gallery experience in the past we have a great network of support and individual strength and determination to take on any challenges that may arise.

The topic we are broaching with this exhibition is a complicated and sensitive one, thus we run the risk of excluding important additions to the dialogue we are trying to generate, however as aspirational curators and theorists we understand the importance of contingency and confliction, our zine which will be produced at the end of the show will be able to raise the concerns that we may find have been left out.

Another way of approaching the issue of what the exhibition actually communicates and might end up leaving out, is the focus on the continuous process of learning, seeing, communicating and collaborating. We will discuss these questions and many more in a panel talk with some of the artists and other thinkers in order to try and move beyond just the exhibition itself onto a wider context.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Updates and Thank You's with one week to go until we open.
updates.update_content:
Another warm Thank You to all our contributors and those who shared our fundraiser with the world. 
We have reached our funding target and that means an enormous amount to us.  The money we have raised covers the costs of printing works, supplying artists with the funds they need to make new works and the general buying and renting of exhibition materials.  
However as first time independent curators we did sightly underestimate our costs, and thus any extra contributions that we can get over the last remaining days in which our Kickstarter is live, will mean we can cover things such as transport for the artists works, printing of exhibition paraphernalia for our audience, as well as helping us to set aside a fund from which we can produce a catalogue in the month following our show, which will allow the show to carry on past its physical actualisation and thus reach those who could not attend.

updates.update_userinfo: The Biggest & Warmest of Thanks to all of you wonderful human beings.
updates.update_content:
In the space of 6 days we have raised £1125, we've have been featured on Kickstarter's 'Art Projects We Love", been featured in an email that goes out to the world, as "1 of 9 new projects" that people should back, and then to top that off, Today, August 3rd, WE ARE "Project of the Day"!!!!
Kickstarter is an amazing platform and we are so thankful for all of the personal support they are giving us, but, we're sure they're support stems from the show of support you guys have provided us with so swiftly!! Confirming to them, that this project has its <3 in the best possible place and that the fundraising you have helped us secure is going to result in a great exhibition with some interesting and much needed dialogue.

campaign.story:
THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF MY HEART! Because of you, life will be a little bit easier for a whole bunch of people.
STRETCH GOALS:
$60,000 will allow us to build your own unique "Feelings Garden". You'll get to choose a flower/plant/animal/etc. emoji to represent how you felt that day and that will get placed in your garden.
$90,000 will allow us to introduce social & community features. You'll be able to create a user profile, and most importantly join our in-app support social network. Imagine your "Feelings Garden" as a place for friends or people you care about to send you encouragement or positivity throughout the day. You'll even be able to send virtual pixel flowers & plants to your friends!
If you've come here wondering... "Who forgets to drink water?", "Who forgets to shower?", "Who forgets to eat?"
The answer? A lot of people.
People living with Mental Illness, people with Chronic Illness, Autistic people, people with ADHD, or simply people who forget to shower, eat, drink, etc. It’s okay to forget! We want to help you remember.
Animation by Tin Kandoic
Easily-navigable 3-screen interface that gives you an active role in your self-care.
Aloe will be a FREE iOS self-care check-in and reminders app that brings essential self-care tasks together in one place. 
It's based off our existing “check-in” survey we designed in January, that thousands of people have used and use daily since. Try it out.
It will help in making sure tasks are getting done, and regularly.
There’s no limit to how many times you check in.
You choose reminders, according to your needs and lifestyle.
Android eventually soon after. We do want our app to be accessible but do need to start somewhere. Please consider backing this and helping us have the possibility.
When you're busy or not feeling that great, it can be hard to remember all the little tasks that make a big difference.
Who is Aloe for?
If you want to be reminded to drink water, brush your teeth, eat/snack, shower, take breaks from social media, etc.
Since the election, many people have expressed a downslide in their emotional well-being. There has been a noticeable shift in interest surrounding self-care and searches for the term hit a five-year high immediately after November 8th, 2016. The problem?
We shouldn’t wait until everything is awful to take care of ourselves.
The Aloe community has already helped thousands. It also has the potential to fill the gap in self-care for some of the most vulnerable and deserving communities: people of color, transgender and queer people, disabled or mentally ill people, and people on a limited income. This app will be the first of its kind, and now more than ever, it needs to exist.
This app does NOT replace mental health care, but it can be a valuable—and free—tool to help fill gaps where needed.
On the check-in screen, you'll find self-care tasks which can be modified in the settings at anytime. You’ll always have the option to remove tasks to avoid the shame spiral that comes with consistently missing them.
DRINK, BREAK, BRUSH, VITAMINS/MEDICATION, SHOWER, SLEEP, SNACK, BE KIND, INDULGE
The tasks emojis will be replaced with custom emoji-like icons designed by Katie Belton (aka Galactic Castle).
Journaling can be time-consuming, but its positive benefits, such as reduced stress, are totally worth it.
Aloe will feature a "reflection space" where users can answer 3 simple questions. Past, present, and future.
Mood.
"How was your day?"
“Who is one person who makes you happy?"
“What is one thing you’ll do for yourself tomorrow?"
Then, mad lib-style, will create a full journal entry. That way it’s quick, easy, and still lets you review your day in emotions and accomplishments. Low impact, high reward.
What better way to feel encouraged than doing these tasks alongside your friends? That's why I designed the foundation for a community in which self-care becomes easy to do and fun to talk about. I believe community should be at the core of every product.
What I'm really excited about is our future vision to create a supportive social network through features like sending encouragement and positivity.
Community features (Opt-in)
Send virtual flowers
Tend to your friends gardens
Community Support Gardens (Imagine doing self-care tasks to help a virtual garden grow, but with friends!)
Although it is not on our launch roadmap, if our goals are exceeded it will become a top priority.
Hi buds, I’m Amber and I build online communities people love.
I’m formerly the founder of Femsplain, creative strategist for Hillary Clinton, Tumblr, and was once the social media manager for Denny’s Diner... but that's another story.
This was the happiest, and lowest emotional point of my life.
While working on the campaign, time management took a back-seat to work, and things like remembering to brush my teeth or drink water became really difficult. My emotional and physical wellness hit an all-time-low.
After it ended, I took a few months to find a healthier headspace and receive support from my communities. That’s when I learned the importance of keeping self-care tasks at top of mind.
I searched the marketplace and came up with nothing but overwhelming habit tools that I inevitably lost the motivation to fulfill. What I needed were tools to reliably “check-in” with myself - ones that wouldn’t shame me if I forgot, but encourage me to stay accountable with gentle notifications.
The only thing that seemed to be good for me was following people on social media who advocated for self-care, creating a system for myself, and holding myself accountable with reminders.
Eventually I figured if I couldn’t find the perfect tools for me, I would just build them.
For development, I've been working with the Lickability team. It's a small iOS software studio in New York. Their team has worked on apps for The New Yorker, Grouper, Meetup, and others.
Is wellness at work something your company cares about? Aloe can be the perfect companion in many tech forward office environments. Teams can encourage one another to keep their emotional wellbeing at top-of-mind, creating a happier more productive environment to work in. Support from your co-workers can go a long way. 
Pledge today and get 1-year of membership for your entire team once our app is released to the public!
Are you a team or organization of 100+?Get in touch! hi@aloe.club
 All backers at the $10+ will receive the following membership perks:
Exclusive (members only) task icon packs
Ability to add new tasks
An even more in-depth look at your self-care data
Aloe app will be completely functional without a membership. Membership once released to the public will be $1 per month.
Founders Garden 
We’re building an interactive Javascript "Garden" on Aloe’s website to thank everyone who supports our campaign. We’ll proudly display your flower or plant, along with your name and a message* for anyone to read.
Check it out on our website.
* We reserve the right to reject text deemed inappropriate. 
Gardeners Club Badge
Inspired by an explorer's badge, show us off proudly on your laptop or anywhere our stickers can stick. Circle stickers are 3" x 3".
Gardeners Club Pin (PROOF OF CONCEPT)
  Send Gold Roses (TWITTER ONLY)
You’ll be given a special ability to send gold roses to your friends, anonymously or not! You’ll be given a special emoji command that your account will be whitelisted to use.
Summon a Bee (TWITTER ONLY)
Not only will you get to summon your very own bee to our Garden, you’ll also get to name them." We’ll also put your bee on top of your flower in the Founders Garden.
* We reserve the right to reject names deemed unacceptable.
Here's our estimated timeline, from conception to execution.
While everything here is not 100% due to estimation changes, we definitely know we need at least $40,000 to build an app we can truly be proud sharing.
P.S. Have you checked-in with yourself today?
Thank you to the following people for their time and support to make this happen.
Mom, Sam, Stefan, Jen, Kim, David, Ngan, Vishnu, Katie, Stef.
Credit: KimHoyos.com for the video!

campaign.story:
Coming to Burning Man 2017—Gigsville presents Lost Cargo.
Lost Cargo exists frozen in time, a moment from crashing, and beckons the participant to insert themselves into a scenario few survive. Participants will enter the cockpit, sit in the captain's seat, and manipulate the controls. Peering through the windshield with their hands on the yoke and their feet on the rudders, they will share the fate of this unfortunate aircraft; through the windscreen they will see fire, and only the darkness of the playa in front of that.
In this moment, who are we?
Who will we be when we walk away?
About the Project:
 Lost Cargo is a full size twin-engine Beechcraft Baron with working navigation lights and intact cockpit, trapped forever in its final flaming moments before it crashes to Earth.
The plane crashing in Tujunga. Next stop BRC!
  Forklifts are really fun, but not so cheap.
Commercial aviation takes an extraordinary fusion of physics, engineering, and innovation and reduces the remarkable achievement of human flight to one of the most degrading capitalistic experiences possible. Lost Cargo seeks to instill in the participant the sense of wonder and awe that we often forget to experience while flying. While gazing through the windscreen of this doomed, burning aircraft, the dark playa in front of them and the sky above, participants will contemplate how fleeting this existence is, and how close we exist to the edge while doing normal, mundane activities.
How We Will Use the Funds:
• Transportation to get this plane to Burning Man
• Transportation to East Jesus for permanent installation
• Buy the final materials we need to make it look awesome
• Propane. Money raised above goal goes right to MORE PROPANE
The Rewards
We are so grateful for your help towards our project! In order to say "thank you," we set up some rewards for all of you—check them out to the right and below!
Patches, dog tags, hoodies will be available for pickup on playa, or shipped after the burn. 
Dogtags and the patch!
  Hoody!
  You can do literally tens of things with these gauges
  Psst. Any you kids want a landing gear?
        Are you in LA and want to pick up a plane with a forklift? Now you can!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
There are standard risks for every big installation at Black Rock City. Dust, wind, vehicle breakdowns, and more. We've got a solid team of experienced builders that know how to build well in this environment, and know how to safely get this erected - and keep it there til we want it to come down.

We've also already gotten the plane from Seattle to LA and mostly re-assembled.

Currently our biggest challenge is financial - this weighs enough that fuel for transportation is a very big expense, and we need to first drive it to site, and then to it's permanent home outside Salton Sea.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Arnar Heiðmar and Phineas
It's 2017--well after the "trans tipping point," or whatever--and yet to our knowledge, there hasn't been an anthology of comics written, drawn, and edited entirely by transgender creators.   
We want to change that—and that’s why we’re asking for your help. 
WE’RE STILL HERE, edited by Tara Avery and Jeanne Thornton, contains fifty-five stories by fifty-five different creators (or creative teams), all of us trans, and all of us telling stories that range from fiction to nonfiction, escapist fantasy to slice-of-life memoir and back again. Here you'll find all the hit trans content you crave: the weird stuff, the stuff that goes to uncomfortable places, the stuff that highlights little-known kinks and contradictions in the trans experience, and most importantly, the stories about trans people having a good, maybe sad time. 
Big talk! But what does it mean in practice? Here's a sampling of the stories in We're Still Here:
An evening discussing the terrors of Donald Trump at a Japanese bar for trans men
A trans woman uses MDMA (with complex results)
A trans woman visits her grandmother for Christmas (with complex results)
Visual essay on sex work, trans masculinity, and testosterone 
A practical guide to using paganism to navigate workplace terror 
Trans women pilot giant robots with impeccable synch ratios 
Toxic masculinity haunts a friendship between a butch lesbian and trans man 
A devotional essay about angels beyond gender or understanding 
Two trans women named Sweetness and Lightning blow up a car, watch Akira, and live happily ever after
If none of these appeal to you, that's okay: we’ve assembled roughly 300 pages of stories from creators both emerging and established, all of them driven by effective narrative, gorgeous art, and sardonic whimsy. We intend this to be the gateway drug to trans comics: a gathering of creators that represents many of the divergent roads that trans comics in the twenty-first century might take. 
We would like this anthology to be swiftly made obsolete by many, many others like it! But the first step is to get this one done, and for that, we need your help!
 For sure! Here is some of what we've received:

Simon Williamson
We have several reasons for you!
Here's one: by backing this project, you’re helping us spread the word that the title promises: we've been here in comics for a long time, and we're not going anywhere soon. In the mainstream comics world, one of us in an anthology can too easily stand in for all of us--assuming that there's an effort to include us at all. Our hope is that this book will showcase just how diverse the body of work trans creators are doing actually is (and that it'll make it easier for future books that propose alternate, maybe better takes on what's interesting in trans comics work to exist.) 
Your pledges also help to forward the conversations between artists and their work that we need. I mean really, you guys: being trans can get lonely! And we mine some of those lonely experiences in our work, sometimes in isolation from the cis creators and friends who're working right beside us. This is why having trans friends, for a trans person, is vital. Being connected to the work of fellow creators who're hacking away at the same problems is no less vital: makes life better and proposes new possibilities and solutions all at once.
Let us get less high-minded, though! If you back this project, we can pay each of the creators involved in this book. This is not negligible! Additionally, for those emerging trans artists we feature here, you're helping to provide needed publication credits and credentials that make it easier to build careers in the editorial gatekeeper-rich comics world. 
Additionally: once the book is successfully financed and we've made back our production and editorial costs, we intend to donate some of the proceeds from each copy of the book sold to Trans Assistance Project (https://www.transassistance.org/) and Sylvia Rivera Law Project (https://srlp.org/). By helping to finance this book, you make it easier for us to do that effectively. 
We've got you covered! :D Most of the money we're raising will go to cover the costs of printing the book, and to pay the artists. 
Our base page rate for finished art from contributors, at the present moment, is $25/page. At roughly 300 pages of artwork, that's going to be around $7,500 in artist payments. Obviously this is not nothing! (But it’s short of what we’d like to be able to pay--see the section on stretch goals below.)
Beyond that, the money will go to covering the costs of printing the book itself, as well as shipping copies of the book to contributors everywhere. Additionally, we’re raising money to pay some of the incidental costs of production (including ISBNs, printers’ proofs, and a book cover.)
Here’s a full breakdown:
$7500: Artist fees
$6000: Printing & drop shipping (~1000 copies, 6" x 9" and estimated 304 pages, full-color PB)
$2000: Shipping + Miscellaneous fees
$1500: Kickstarter + payment processing fees
Total: $17000.
We will have more information about this once we've launched--the first priority is to get to $17,000! But at present, the rough expectation is that stretch goals will happen roughly every $2,500 to $3,000 above the initial goal, and each stretch goal will result in the artists' pay rate being increased by about $5/page across the board. This means that most of the stretch goal money will, to the extent that it's possible, go directly to the artists. We'll have more information on this as soon as possible.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We began working on this anthology way back in summer of 2016. We spent most of that year and the early months of 2017 carefully assembling our list of contributors (both from solicitations and from an open call for submissions, to try to get as many creators as possible on board.) As we prepare this Kickstarter text, the bulk of the work on the anthology is underway, with several of the finished pieces already received and others in process, with delivery expected through July and August 2017 and a projected pub date of either very late 2017 or very early 2018. 

Both editors have published professionally for some time, and it's a given--especially with fifty-six artists!--that delays will be inevitable! But we've built expected delays into our editorial and production timelines, and at present we’re on track to meet all of our deadlines for finishing the editorial and production work by early Fall 2017.

In terms of the risks of the Kickstarter itself: both the editors of We're Still Here have previously published successfully Kickstarted anthologies (ALPHABET from Stacked Deck Press and Nerve Endings: The New Trans Erotic from Instar Books.) Believe me that we are both *very, very aware* of the potential challenges involved with running a successful Kickstarter and fulfilling rewards to all backers! We’ve learned from our experiences, and we intend to keep a clear line of communication going with backers in order to ensure a smooth delivery of rewards.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Stacked Deck Press presents Crush: First Love, New Talent!
updates.update_content:
SDP and Prism Comics team up again for an all-new anthology!
Stacked Deck Press and Prism Comics conducted a talent search for up and coming queer comics creators to bring you Crush: First Love, New Talent! This anthology features 24 stories by 24 cartoonists and creative teams on the topic of young love! Co-editor Viktor Kerney and I made a special effort to front load representation from creators of emerging identities. In addition to embracing asexual, genderqueer, trans, and nonbinary cartoonists, we also have represented the rest of the LGBTQAIU spectrum! Check out the Kickstarter campaign for this special book!

updates.update_userinfo: We're Still Here at Queers & Comics in New York! Backer Rewards Shipped!
updates.update_content:
If you have completed your survey, your backer rewards have shipped!
I wrapped up the last handful of packages today. If you have filled out your backer reward survey, your rewards have shipped to the address listed. Thank you all for your patience during this process. I learned a lot, again, on this Kickstarter, and the mistakes made will not be repeated in future campaigns. There are some backer rewards that have returned to me undeliverable, and I will start sorting them out after I return from...
Queers & Comics Conference in New York City!

updates.update_userinfo: Transgender Heroes Coloring Book has arrived! Remaining backer rewards ship this week!
updates.update_content: We received our shipment of the Transgender Heroes Coloring Book from the printer today! With these in hand I can ship the remaining backer rewards this week! Thank you for your patience and happy coloring!

updates.update_userinfo: We're Still Here is a Lambda Literary Award Finalist!
updates.update_content:
We're Still Here is a Lammy Graphic Novel Finalist!
We're Still Here has been nominated for a 2019 Lambda Literary Award in the category of LGBTQ Graphic Novel. Congratulations to Jeanne Thornton and all the contributors! Thank you all for your patience and support! The winners of the Lammys will be announced June 3 in New York City.

updates.update_userinfo: Transgender Heroes Coloring Book Finished! Remaining Backer Rewards to Ship in May!
updates.update_content:
The Transgender Heroes Coloring Book has gone to print!
With a little help from Calogrenant author Gillian Cameron, the Transgender Heroes Coloring Book is complete and at the printer! It features illustrations and biographies of 45 real-life transgender heroes from Roman Emperor Elagabalus to Stonewall icon Marsha P. Johnson! The images were drawn by contributors to We're Still Here with additional contributions by Cameron and Andi Santagata! So, this means...

Another batch of international backer rewards went out today! This leaves fewer than 60 rewards left to ship for about 3% of our backers!
So, what’s left to go out? We still need to ship rewards packages including coloring books, to backers both domestic and international, and the backer rewards that were returned to me undeliverable. Otherwise your rewards should be in your hands or on their way.
Look for another update very soon. Thank you all very, very much for your patience and support! We’re almost done!

updates.update_userinfo: Where We Are and Where I've Been
updates.update_content:
Over 90% of Backer Rewards have shipped, and I will begin shipping the remainder this week.
Hello. First, my sincere apologies for the delay to this update. I have been beset by personal and financial challenges that have eased only recently. We have to date shipped backer rewards to over 90% of the people who have answered their survey, and this week we will begin fulfillment for the rest. Over the past several months I have shipped a few dozen backer rewards as my circumstances have permitted, but I understand any frustration with this pace. I will be speeding things up beginning immediately.

updates.update_userinfo: We are in fact still here!
updates.update_content:
Hi folks! Have been reading backer comments, and although I don't have breaking news about the fulfillment process, I don't want you guys have to wait longer for some kind of word from us.
The word is, unfortunately, still going to be inconclusive. I do know that books have gone out and are continuing to go out, although there's been some delay. I don't have a specific update on the final piece of fulfillment, but I know Tara is working on it, and everyone will get books as soon as we can!

You got somethin' you wanna tote around?
Because now you can do it in your own, snappy We're Still Here tote bag!

updates.update_userinfo: Fulfillment Update and Upcoming SDP Events!
updates.update_content:
We're Still Here Fulfillment over two-thirds finished!
First off, thank you all for your patience and your support. We're Still Here is the largest and most successful Kickstarter campaign I've done, and I did not realize the sheer amount of time it would take me to fulfill four times as many backer rewards as I ever have before. Right now, I have shipped out all domestic backer rewards, and most of the international, for the $25 level and below. Those levels alone comprised well over half of the backer rewards. I am now working on the $30 level, and since I changed my shipping materials, stuffing the mailers has gone much, MUCH faster. Here's a sample from Tuesday...

campaign.story:
Hi, it's me, Nadya from Pussy Riot.
This is important: I’m asking for your support in an exciting new project. Pussy Riot, together with the award-winning, London-based theatre company Les Enfants Terribles, is working on a breakthrough immersive theatre project that will open in London this November.
This wild theatrical experience will allow the audience to become a participant, experiencing exactly what Pussy Riot went through during our imprisonment - from the original Church performance, to the court trial and prison cells. We're going to recreate Russian courtrooms, a real Russian labour colony, solitary confinement cells, priests who shout about banning abortions and many more absurd, but real-life things that exist in Russia today.
The audience will actually get the chance to re-live each one of these experiences themselves, learning what it means to be a political opponent in Russia today. We’ll take you on a journey from the cathedral altar deep into the vaults of the Kremlin itself. Hopefully, this is a journey that you’ll only have to make once in your life.
We're hoping that this production will be funded by regular people from around the world who are excited about the idea of political immersive theatre, and we need your help! In order to ensure its launch we need to pre-fund this high-tech production - and fast. All the money raised will be spent on renting the space, the set design, employing actors and staff for the show’s 6-week run and making those rooms in London look exactly like solitary confinement cells in the Russian prison I did my time in.
This is an important project that has immense educational value, especially given the trying times in which we are living and an increasingly scary political world order. If we do it right, the production is set to be mind-blowing.
We only have four weeks, let’s do this!
Pussy Riot stickers
The Connor Brothers print
The BEAUTIFUL T-shirt
REVOLUTION series print by Amanita
Pussy Riot T-Shirt
Russian Alphabet Colouring Book
                              Pussy Riot print by Jonas Akerlund
Original Pussy Riot print
Print by Amanita (click for more information)
The creators of the show from Les Enfants Terribles Theatre Company have this to say about the project:  
"Creating an immersive and detailed world is an inherently expensive proposition but something we believe is important in order to truly transport audiences into a realistic environment that fully serves the Pussy Riot story. Now is a perfect time to remind audiences what actually happened and how one’s basic human rights and freedom of expression can be taken away at any point."
Les Enfants Terribles Theatre company are an award-winning London based company known for their innovative productions that vividly bring exciting worlds to audiences all around the world. Their focus on immersive shows brought to us such successful shows as "Alice's Adventures Underground", "Dinner at the Twits" and "The Games Afoot".
Producer of the show, Alexandrina Markvo, explains the inspiration behind the project as follows: 
"Our goal is not just to create a breakthrough piece of theatre, but to develop something that can promote the cause of human rights protection, educate people about the problems in Russian legal and judicial processes and give audiences an idea of how fragile our seemingly safe society actually is." 
Creative director Alexandrina Markvo founded the London-based company Bird&Carrot, which specialises in theatre, music and visual arts. B&C works on a wide spectrum of artistic projects involving not only world-famous performers, but also those who are just starting out on their creative journeys. What the company values above all is freedom of creative expression. Markvo's previous production credits include Brodsky/Baryshnikov at the Apollo Theatre in 2017, Boris Grebenschikov concerts at the Royal Geographical Society, Zemfira at the V&A in 2008.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We’re going to be 100% honest. 

Our biggest risk is that the show will not happen if we fail to achieve our funding goal. This is a genuine possibility - it’s hard to convince people that they should sponsor theatre - which is why we need as much help as we can get! So please, if you are not able to pledge money towards the project, share this page with your family, friends and instagram followers. 

Please scroll down for a more detailed Q&A, answering questions about costs and the production itself.

**********************************************************************************************


Q: Why do you need this amount of money? What is it going to be spent on?

A: In order to make an impact and to powerfully draw the spectator into the action, immersive theatre is usually a very high tech, high cost production. Just take a look at this trailer for Les Enfants Terribles' current show: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NC70wHBwuWA

Funds will go towards the intricate set design, costumes, necessary licenses, lighting and special effects, virtual reality technology and other technologies used in immersive theatre.

So that more people get the chance to see and learn from our production we are aiming to secure the show at the venue for a 6-week run. This entails the longer employment of actors, technicians and other staff: employing people at proper rates is very important to us. On top of this, we are renting the space for a longer period of time. 

The more money we can raise, the better and more exciting the production will be! 

Q: Why don't you just give the money raised to political NGOs working in Russia? Surely this is a better use of the money?

A: We already run an NGO, Zona Prava http://zonaprava.com/en/ - an advocacy group which is entirely dedicated to raising awareness about the prison system and prisoners in Russian today. We also run our own media organisation, Media Zona, https://zona.media/ . I guess most of you reading this won't have heard of these organisations or the work that they do - and that's the point. We want to educate more people about the harsh realities facing Russians today (as well as other prisoners across the world), realities that given the current world political order could potentially spread to the West itself very soon. Freedom of speech is a luxury — we need to powerfully and tangibly remind people of that in a way that they are not used to.

Q: What happens if you don't raise the money?

A: If we don't reach our £60,000 goal we won't see a single penny. Backers credit cards will never be charged - this only happens once a campaign is successful. This is why we need you to share this page and encourage your friends and family to pledge some money so that we can see this ambitious, exciting project become a reality. It would be such a great shame if this theatrical collaboration was not realised and we truly believe that people would miss out on a unique and groundbreaking experience. 

Q: Will Pussy Riot themselves be performing in the show?

A: Yes, Nadya will be performing in a selection of shows.

Q. Is the production suitable for children?

Yes, definitely - however, we would recommend that the production is suitable for children of 11-12 and older. We actively encourage kids to participate. We are hoping to organise school visits and to provide educational packs and brochures. The pack will include details about the most famous cases of prisoner abuse in different countries.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter
